Brown-bagging as defined herein is prohibited within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo. Upon conviction, such persons shall be punished pursuant to the provisions of section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 2, 1-27-05) 
Secs. 4-13—4-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATING REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-26. - Hours—Daily, Sundays, holidays. 
(a)  Daily and Sunday hours. 
(1)  Packaged beer or wine locations: 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any licensee licensed to sell packaged beer or wine hereunder to permit the sale or engage in the sale of such beer or wine except from 5:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday. For security purposes, if any work is needed to be done during legally closed hours, the police department must be notified at least one (1) hour in advance. 
b.  Hotels, motels, grocery stores, service stations and restaurants shall not be required to close unrelated functions and activities not licensed under this chapter or customarily operated at hours other than the foregoing specified hours, but all alcoholic beverages of any nature must be and remain in the custody and control of the licensee or his employees, and may not be dispensed in any manner, and the licensee is hereby required to evict any other person possessing any of the above. 
(2)  Beer or wine on-the-premises consumption: 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any licensee licensed to sell beer or wine to permit the sale or engage in the sale of such beer or wine except from 5:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight. All customers will clear the premises no later than 1:00 a.m. on Sundays, and all owners and employees shall vacate the premises before 2:00 a.m. on weekdays and before 2:00 a.m. on Sundays. For security purposes, if any work is needed to be done during legally closed hours, the police department must be notified at least one (1) hour in advance. 
b.  Hotels, motels, grocery stores, service stations and restaurants shall not be required to close unrelated functions and activities not licensed under this chapter or customarily operated at hours other than the foregoing specified hours, but all alcoholic beverages of any nature must be and remain in the custody and control of the licensee or his employees, and may not be dispensed in any manner, and the licensee is hereby required to evict any other person possessing any of the above. For the purpose of this paragraph, "restaurant" shall be defined by the definition of that word contained in subparagraph (a)(13) of section 4-38 of this Code. 
(3)  Liquor pouring: 
a.  On-the-premises consumption. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell alcoholic beverages except during the hours of 5:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight Monday through Thursday and Saturday. All customers will clear the premises no later than 1:00 a.m. on weekdays and Sunday and all owners and employees shall vacate the premises before 2:00 a.m. on weekdays and Sunday except as set forth herein. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell alcoholic beverages except during the hours of 5:00 a.m. on Friday to 1:00 a.m. on Saturday. All customers will clear the premises no later than 2:00 a.m. on Saturday and all owners and employees shall vacate the premises before 3:00 a.m. on Saturday. For security purposes, if any work is needed to be done during legally closed hours, the police department must be notified at least one hour in advance. 
b.  Hotels, motels and restaurants shall not be required to close unrelated functions and activities not licensed under this chapter or customarily operated at hours other than the foregoing specified hours, but all alcoholic beverages of any nature must be and remain in the custody and control of the licensee or his employees, and may not be dispensed in any manner, and the licensee is hereby required to evict any other person possessing any of the above. 
(4)  Package liquor stores: Licensees shall not engage in the sale of any commodity except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(5)  Wholesalers: The business hours of any wholesaler licensed hereunder shall be from sunrise to sunset, exclusive of Sunday. 
(b)  Holidays. 
(1)  Packaged liquor: Except as hereinafter provided, no licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package at retail shall permit his place of business to be open on Sunday. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell any alcoholic beverage at a package beer or wine location, beer or wine for on premises consumption, or liquor under a pouring license during Christmas Day. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 302, §§ 1, 2, 5-27-86; Ord. No. 310, § 1, 3-9-87; Ord. No. 323, §§ 1, 2, 2-8-88; Ord. No. 572, § 1, 2-25-02) 
Sec. 4-27. - Persons under legal age; exception. 
(a)  Furnishing. It shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in section 4-3 of the City Code for any person holding an alcoholic beverage license, or any other person, or his or her agent or employee, to sell or give away, or permit the sale or gift of any alcoholic beverage to any person under legal age, except for medical purposes pursuant to a prescription of a physician [duly authorized to practice medicine in this state, or in the home with parental] consent. No person shall be convicted under this section if such person has been furnished with proper identification showing that the person who is being furnished alcoholic beverages is of legal age or over. For purposes of this section, the term "proper identification" means any document issued by a government agency containing a description of the person, with the person's photograph, and giving the person's date of birth, and includes, without being limited to, a passport, military identification card, driver's license, or Georgia identification card. The licensee shall cause all persons who appear to be near the legal age to exhibit, and the licensee or his employee shall inspect, one of the means of identification allowed above. 
(b)  Consumption, possession. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in section 4-3, of the City Code for any person under legal age to purchase or possess any alcoholic beverage except for medical purposes pursuant to the prescription of a physician duly authorized to practice medicine in this state, or in the home with parental consent. 
(c)  Attempting to purchase or possess alcoholic beverage. It shall be unlawful for any person under legal age to attempt to purchase or possess any alcoholic beverage. 
(d)  Use of fake, etc., credentials. It shall be unlawful for any person under legal age to exhibit fake, forged or borrowed credentials in an effort to obtain alcoholic beverages to which he or she is not entitled. 
(e)  Underage persons on licensed premises. No person who holds an alcoholic beverage license allowing on-the-premises consumption, or his agent or employee, shall allow any person who has not attained legal age to be in, frequent, or loiter about the licensed premises unless such person is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, or unless such person is an employee of the license holder; provided, however, that such person shall be permitted in restaurants or other places serving food without being accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. The provisions of this section shall not apply to a person in the military service who has reached the age of eighteen (18) years and who has on his or her person a valid military identification card. 
(f)  Employment of persons—Legal age. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as prohibiting any person of legal age from: 
(1)  Dispensing, serving, selling, taking orders or handling alcoholic beverages as a part of employment in any licensed establishment. 
(2)  Being employed in any establishment in which alcoholic beverages are distilled or manufactured. 
(3)  Taking orders for, and having possession of, alcoholic beverages as a part of employment in a licensed establishment. 
(4)  The provisions of this section shall not prohibit persons under legal age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries or drugstores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off-the-premises. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 302, § 3, 5-27-86; Ord. No. 306, § 1, 8-11-86; Ord. No. 328, § 1, 5-23-88) 
Secs. 4-28—4-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPECIAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 4-36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 303, § 1, adopted July 16, 1986, deleted § 4-36 in its entirety. Said section pertained to on-premises beer and wine consumption and seating capacity of drinking establishments, and was derived from Ord. No. 299, adopted May 5, 1986. 
Sec. 4-37. - Distilled spirits, packaged liquor. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Adequate parking shall mean one parking space for each two hundred fifty (250) square feet of gross floor area within the store building of the applicant, but not less than a minimum of six (6) spaces. Such off-street parking shall have vehicular access to streets and be constructed of allweather surface; all off-street parking must be on the premises and located adjacent to the sides or front of the building. Such parking shall be designed to allow for separate and coordinate lanes of ingress and egress, and if a drive-in window is made available to the public, it must be situated so that there may be space for as many as three (3) cars waiting in turn for service at such window. On the entire business premises relating to all businesses located thereon as allowed in subsection (j), the parking spaces shall not be less than the total required under this section, together with other parking ordinance requirements of the city for all of said businesses. 
(2)  Alcoholic beverages shall mean distilled spirits as defined in section 4-1(3). 
(3)  Business area shall mean any area which is correspondingly zoned in accordance with the City of Cairo zoning ordinance. 
(4)  Family shall mean and include any person related to the holder of a license issued under the provisions of this section within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as determined according to the law of this state. 
(5)  Fortified wines are classed as liquor and shall mean any wines or beverages made by fermentation, to which there have been added distilled spirits and where the alcoholic content is more than twenty-one (21) per cent alcohol by volume. 
(6)  License shall mean the authorization by the governing authority of the City of Cairo to engage in the sale of packaged alcoholic beverages on the premises for a calendar year, or the remaining portion of a calendar year. 
(7)  Licensee shall mean a person or persons, real or artificial, holding any class of license issued under the terms of this section. 
(8)  Manufacturer shall mean a producer or bottler of beer or wine. 
(9)  Package store shall mean a geographic location within the City of Cairo wherein a license may be issued for the sale of packaged liquors. Such package store must be operated as a distinct business and cannot be operated in conjunction with or as a part of any other business, except as provided in this section. 
(10)  Person shall mean an individual or individuals, a partnership or partnerships, a corporation or corporations and an association or associations. 
(11)  Premises shall mean that area circumscribed by the property lines of the property upon which a licensee is authorized to operate a package liquor store. 
(12)  Private residence shall mean a house, dwelling or building wherein not less than one family customarily resides. This shall not apply to any of the above which has been unoccupied for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months immediately prior to the filing of an application hereunder. 
(13)  Retail sale shall mean selling or offering for sale alcoholic beverages to any member of the public. 
(14)  Visibility shall mean a full and unobstructed view of the inside service area through at least sixty (60) per cent of one exterior wall fronting on a traveled street, or forty (40) per cent of each of two (2) exterior walls, at least one of which fronts on a traveled street. The percentages herein are to be calculated on the surface area from floor to ceiling of any of the chosen walls and doorways circumscribing the customer service and display area. The required visibility required hereunder may not be blocked by any signs nor by vending machines, displays or other obstructions. Visibility shall include inside illumination at all times of the day and night of at least ten (10) footcandles in any part of the customer service and display area. 
(15)  Wholesaler shall mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in distribution or selling to retailers for the purpose of resale, any alcoholic beverages as defined herein. 
(b)  Citizenship, residence requirement. 
(1)  No license for the retail sale of packaged liquor by the package shall be granted to any applicant who has not resided continuously within the State of Georgia for a period of twelve (12) months next preceding the date on which the application is made, except that the wholesalers or distillers are exempt from this residency provision. Where the applicant is a corporation, which may be a newly formed corporation, all officers and stockholders in such corporation, and all officers and stockholders in any corporation which holds stock in the applicant corporation, or any further extension of corporate interest must meet the requirements contained in this paragraph. If the applicant is a partnership, the requirements contained in this paragraph must be met by all partners, whether general or limited. All licensees that sell packaged liquor must remain a resident of the State of Georgia during the tenure of their license. 
(2)  All applicants including partners and stockholders having an interest in an applying corporation, or in any corporation having an interest in the applicant corporation, shall furnish all data, information and records pertinent to the application requested of them by the police department of the city, which shall include fingerprints, except in the case of any corporate stockholders when an officer of the corporation making the application shall be fingerprinted, and failure to furnish such data, information and records within thirty (30) days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to dismiss, with prejudice, the application. All applicants shall submit an executed version, for city purposes only as modified by the city clerk, of the personnel statement Form ATT-17, State of Georgia Department of Revenue, Alcohol Tax and Control Unit. The applicants, by filing an application agree to produce for oral interrogation any person or persons requested by the police department of the city and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such application and/or license issued under the terms of this section. The failure to produce such person or persons within thirty (30) days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of any application pending under this section. 
(c)  Advertisement of application for license to engage in business; signs posted. 
(1)  All applicants for original licenses hereunder shall give notice of the making of an application by advertisement at least once a week, for three (3) consecutive weeks prior to the date of hearing on such application, in the weekly newspaper published in the city in which the legal advertisements of the city are published, which notice shall contain the location of the proposed business and shall give the name of the applicant, and if a partnership, the name of all of the partners, whether limited or general, and if a corporation, the names of the officers and all stockholders therein and the names of all officers and stockholders of any corporation owning an interest in the applicant corporation, and the date and time the mayor and council will hear such application. The advertisement referred to herein shall be of type not smaller than ten-point capital and lower case and shall be at least a two-inch, two-column advertisement. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant for an original license to advertise the notice of hearing as required as follows: 
"Notice of application for retail license to sell packaged liquors. 
The undersigned has made application to the Mayor and Council of the City of Cairo for a retail license to sell packaged liquors at ____________ . This application will be heard by the Mayor and Council at its meeting to be held at ____________ o'clock p.m. on the ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 

(2)  The applicant shall cause to be placed upon the location of the proposed business for a week before the date of hearing, a sign or signs stating the following: 
"PACKAGE LIQUOR LICENSE APPLIED FOR. HEARING BEFORE THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL FOR THE CITY OF CAIRO, GEORGIA, ON THE ____________ DAY OF ____________ , 19 ____________ ." 
(3)  The sign or signs required by subsection (2) shall be not less that twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches and shall face toward all public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public property adjoining the proposed location. Such signs shall be placed where they can be easily seen from all public properties adjoining the proposed location. 
(d)  Limitation on number of licenses within a family and/or corporation. 
(1)  No person and/or member of his family and/or corporation shall own, hold or control any interest whatsoever in more than one license in the City of Cairo to engage in the business of selling alcoholic beverages by the package at retail. 
(2)  As used in this paragraph, an interest in the license shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license, a co-owner of a license, a general or limited partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license, a stockholder in any corporation which owns all or any part of a license, an owner or leasing any real estate which is occupied by a retail liquor store, or shares in any income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having any interest in a retail liquor store. 
(3)  All applications for license made on forms provided by the city clerk, whether original or for renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement under oath of information relative to any and all interests, as hereinbefore defined in subsection (2), in retail liquor stores. This shall include the names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business of selling packaged liquor at retail, together with any interest each person or members of his family has in any other retail liquor store; the ownership of the land and building where such retail business is operated; the amount of rental paid for said land and building and the manner in which the same is determined and to whom and at what intervals it is paid; the name and address (by affidavit from owner, lessor or sublessor of such land and building) of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial or any other interest in and to the land and building on and in which said retail liquor store is to be located; a copy of the proposed lease, and any other information requested by the police department or the mayor and council pertinent to the application under investigation. 
(e)  Conducting a public hearing on original application. 
(1)  No original application for a license hereunder shall be acted upon or issued by the mayor and council until after advertisement and public hearing thereon, as required in subsection (c) of this section. 
(2)  A public hearing upon all original and completed applications for a license hereunder shall be called by the mayor and council for a regular meeting not more than sixty (60) days after the filing of the application. 
(3)  Each applicant for an original license shall submit a plot plan and floor plan prepared by an architect, engineer, contractor, surveyor or other qualified person showing all compliance with all requirements contained in this section. 
(f)  Minimum requirements; floor space of retail outlet, parking required, adequate refuse storage required, visibility from exterior. 
(1)  Any structure housing a licensed retail package store, or proposed therefor, under the terms of this section, shall contain not less than one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space, including customer service and display area, storage area and service areas. 
(2)  Adequate parking shall be provided as defined elsewhere in this section. Adequate refuse storage space shall be provided with access for servicing by refuse collection vehicles. 
(3)  The store so occupied for retail sales shall be constructed so that three (3) entire outside walls can be seen from the exterior, and visibility, as defined elsewhere in this section, must be provided from the exterior into the customer service and display area. Visibility, as required, may not be blocked by any signs, vending machines, displays or other obstructions. 
(g)  Completion of proposed licensed premises. Where a building in which a retailer proposes to operate under the provisions of this section is, at the time of application for such license, not in existence, or not yet completed, a license may be approved for such location provided the plans and specifications for the proposed building are filed with the city clerk of Cairo and show clearly a compliance with the other provisions of this section and applicable ordinances of the city. No license shall then be issued and no sales shall be allowed in such establishment until it has been completed in accordance with all other provisions of this section and other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(h)  Acceptance and consideration of application after rejection. When any license or permit to operate a retail package store under this section is rejected by the mayor and council, the city clerk shall not accept, and the mayor and council shall not consider, any application from the applicant for a license within twelve (12) months from the time of such rejection by the mayor and council. 
(i)  Time limit for commencement of business in licensed establishments; forfeiture for nonuse. Any holder of a license hereunder who shall begin the operation of the business authorized in the license, but who shall for a period of six (6) consecutive months thereafter cease to operate the business as authorized in said license, shall, upon expiration of such six-month period, automatically forfeit such license, which license shall by virtue of such failure to operate, be cancelled without the necessity of any further action of the mayor and council and no refund of license fee shall be made to the license holder; provided, however, that a license holder may apply to the mayor and council to cease business operations for a period not to exceed an additional six (6) months for such reasons as building renovation, illness, or other such reasons as the mayor and council in its discretion may approve. 
(j)  Restrictions on adjoining businesses. 
(1)  A licensee of a retail establishment under this section shall not operate such business in the same store together with any other business, except licensed packaged beer and wine, which may be in a connected adjoining store selling packaged beer and wine if such packaged beer and wine store sells only beer, wine and other items of convenience normally associated with the retail sale of packaged beer and wine, and then only if such packaged beer and wine is sold for carry-out purposes, and provided further, that there shall be a cash register in both such authorized adjoining operations. No such retailer shall sell, offer for sale, display or keep in stock in his place of business where packaged alcoholic beverages are offered for sale, any other commodity or product, except: 
a.  Packaged wine (if licensed); 
b.  Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits, but no beverages of any kind may be opened or consumed in said place of business; and 
c.  Packaged beer (if licensed); 
d.  Packaged ice; 
e.  Tobacco products; and 
f.  Sealed packages of empty cups. 
(2)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this paragraph, any legal business may adjoin or abut either or both a package liquor store and package beer and wine store, provided all building requirements in this section are met; and provided further that there shall be no doorways whatsoever located between any adjoining businesses other than between businesses neither of which is licensed to sell beer, wine, or distilled spirits, except a door is authorized between adjoining package liquor and package beer and wine stores which may be unlocked only between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday. 
(k)  Exterior signs. Each business occupying a building under the terms and provisions of this section shall be entitled to erect signs (see section 22-391 et seq.) that comply with all ordinances regarding signs currently within effect in the City of Cairo and comply with requirements of state law applying to exterior signs. All signs shall be unilluminated and use letters not larger than eight (8) inches in height flat against the outside of building, below the roofline, bearing the words "liquor", "beer", "wine", "champagne", or any combination thereof, and "package store" or "liquor store", together with the trade name of the retail dealer. In addition to such signs flat against the outside of the building, the retail dealer may display at a location on the tract of property upon which the business is located, but not affixed to the building, one unilluminated sign using letters not larger than eight (8) inches in height bearing the words "package store" or "liquor store" and the trade name of the retail dealer. A sign not affixed to the building may be no larger than sixteen (16) square feet in area. The trade name or style of the retailer as listed on the application form submitted to the city clerk, and approved by the mayor and council, in compliance with this section must be the same name used on the sign. 
(l)  Coin-operated devices, similar machines on premises. It shall be unlawful for a retail dealer in spirituous liquors by the package to permit any gambling on the premises by use of coin-operated devices and it shall be unlawful for any person to play or operate for the purpose of gambling, pinball machines, machines for amusement purposes, coin-operated machines for dispensing tobacco products or packaged ice and the violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 9-3 of the City Code. 
(m)  Consumption prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on premises licensed for the sale of packaged liquor and it shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises. If such licensee shall also have a license to sell beer or wine, it shall likewise be unlawful for any of such items to be consumed on the premises where alcoholic beverage sale is licensed. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 302, § 4, 5-27-86; Ord. No. 303, § 2, 7-16-86; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 681, § 3, 4-28-08; Ord. No. 775, § 1, 7-27-15; Ord. No. 787, § 1, 9-26-16) 
Sec. 4-38. - Liquor pouring. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Alcoholic beverages shall mean distilled spirits as defined in section 4-1(2) or the mixing of beverages with same. 
(2)  Fortified wines shall mean any wines or other beverages made by fermentation; to which there have been added distilled spirits, and where the alcoholic content is more than twenty-one (21) per cent alcohol by volume, are classed as liquor. 
(3)  License shall mean the authorization by the mayor and council of the City of Cairo to engage in the sale of distilled spirits or alcoholic beverages by the drink on the premises. 
(4)  Licensee shall mean a person or persons, real or artificial, holding any class of license issued under the terms of this section. 
(5)  Lounge shall mean a separate room connected with a part of and adjacent to the herein licensed premises of a restaurant and/or its adjacent lobby or reception area, with all booths, stools and tables being open to view only from within the lounge. All lounges shall have a seating capacity for at least twenty (20) persons. All access and all exits to and from the lounge shall open into the restaurant and/or lobby or reception area adjoining the restaurant except that emergency exits or doors solely for service or delivery personnel are authorized. 
(6)  Manufacture shall mean a producer or bottler of beer, wine or distilled spirits. 
(7)  Person shall mean an individual or individuals, a partnership or partnerships, a corporation or corporations and association or associations. 
(8)  Premises shall mean the definite closed or partitioned-in locality, whether room, shop or building, wherein distilled spirits are sold. 
(9)  Licensed premises with reference to a fifty (50) guest room hotel or motel, shall mean the boundary lines of the property on which the same is located, including specifically guest rooms and open areas serviced as enclosed areas. 
(10)  Fifty (50) room hotel or motel shall mean that business establishment containing a minimum of fifty (50) guest rooms for transient occupancy and constructed to normal size and condition for the hotel or motel industry. 
(11)  Private club shall mean an organization existing under the law of the State of Georgia or a charter from a state or national parent organization, and having a tax-exempt status under Section 501 of the U.S. IRS Code, having at least fifty (50) members regularly paying monthly, quarterly, semiannual or annual dues, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes, owning, hiring or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment for cooking, preparing and serving meals for its members or guests; provided, that no member or officer, agent, or employee of the club is paid or directly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages to the club or its members or guests beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at any annual meeting or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club. 
(12)  Private residence shall mean a house, dwelling or building wherein not less than one family customarily resides. This shall not apply to any of the above which has been unoccupied for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months immediately prior to the filing of an application hereunder. 
(13)  Restaurant shall mean any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually and regularly prepared and served from 11:00 a.m., until 9:00 p.m. 
(14)  Retail sale shall mean selling or offering for sale alcoholic beverages to any member of the public by pouring for on-the-premises consumption. 
(15)  School shall mean only such state, county, city or other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state and shall not include private schools where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects are taught. 
(16)  Wholesaler shall mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in distribution or selling to retailers for the purpose of resale any alcoholic beverages as defined herein. 
(b)  Information, data, records, processing of application. 
(1)  All applicants shall furnish all reasonable data, information and records requested of them by the police department and failure to furnish such data, information and records within thirty (30) days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to dismiss, with prejudice, the application. The individual owner applying, or one partner, or one corporate officer shall be fingerprinted for city purposes, except that in the case any of the above has current prints of file as a privilege licensee of the city, this requirement may be waived. Notwithstanding this provision, however, city officials may require fingerprints from other partners or corporate officers, and new set of prints from the above referred to privilege licensees. Applicants, by filing an application, agree to produce for oral interrogation any person or persons requested by the police department and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such license. The failure to produce such person or persons within thirty (30) days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of such application. 
(2)  The city may require sixty (60) days for processing any application for license required under this section. 
(c)  Advertisement by an original applicant of intent to engage in business; signs posted. 
(1)  All applicants for original licenses hereunder shall give notice of the purpose of making such application by advertisement at least once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks prior to the hearing, in the weekly paper published in the city in which legal advertisements of the city are carried, which notice shall contain the location of the proposed business and shall give the name of the applicant, and if a partnership, the names of the partners, and if a corporation, the names of the officers, and the date and time the mayor and council would hear the application. The advertisement referred to herein shall be of type not smaller than ten-point capital and lower case and shall be at least a two-inch, two-column advertisement. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant for an original license to advertise the notice of hearing as required as follows: 
"Notice of application for retail license for liquor pouring (mixed drinks). 
The undersigned has made application to the Mayor and Council of the City of Cairo for a retail license for liquor pouring (mixed drinks) at ____________ . This application will be heard by the Mayor and Council at its meeting to be held at ____________ o'clock p.m. on the ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 

(2)  The applicant shall cause to be placed on the location of the proposed business for a week before the hearing a sign stating the following: 
"LIQUOR POURING LICENSE APPLIED FOR, HEARING BEFORE THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF CAIRO, GEORGIA, ON THE ____________ DAY OF ____________ , 19 ____________ ." 
The sign or signs shall be not less than twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches and shall face towards all public property which adjoins the location. Such signs shall be placed where they can be easily seen from all public properties adjoining the location. 
(d)  Investigation of application; report. All applications required by this section shall be investigated by the police department and acted upon by the mayor and council after investigation has been completed by the police department and their report presented to the mayor and council. 
(e)  General requirements of business licensed hereunder. No application for any license hereunder shall be granted unless the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Licenses shall be granted only to private clubs or restaurants which may include lounges operated in conjunction with such restaurants. 
(2)  All restaurants applying for or having pouring licenses must, in addition to all other requirements relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink, meet and maintain the following requirements: 
a.  Meet all health and sanitation requirements set forth for food service establishments by the city, state and federal government. 
b.  Must have installed and operative cooking facilities and kitchen equipment for accommodating the demands of sixty (60) food customers. 
c.  Must have a complete place setting of metal cutlery and nondisposable dishes in regular use for each of sixty (60) food customers. 
d.  Must have seating, at booths or tables designed for food service, sufficient for at least sixty (60) persons, and such booths or tables shall be large enough to accommodate at least two (2) place settings of metal cutlery and nondisposable dishes. 
e.  Such a restaurant as contemplated by this section shall be, at all times during the hours hereinafter set forth, prepared to serve full-course meals with a substantial variety of culinary choices, or substantial substitutes therefor, and shall print and maintain a complete menu of same and furnish such printed menu to each food customer, with prices which are competitive with other restaurants within the city, whether or not those restaurants engage in the business of pouring mixed drinks. 
f.  All foods listed on the required printed menu, or substantial substitutes therefor, must be available from 11:00 a.m., until 9:00 p.m., or if all sales of mixed drinks are stopped before 9:00 p.m., then from 11:00 a.m., until such earlier time as all mixed drink sales have ceased, at least five (5) days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations, and periods of redecorating. The hours for service of food may be prolonged, but in no event shall mixed drinks be sold at any hour contrary to this chapter. 
(3)  The gross square footage of the dining area, lounge area, serving area, kitchen, restrooms and storage rooms of any restaurant business other than private clubs, licensed hereunder must be a minimum of two thousand (2,000) square feet. Parking requirements for restaurants licensed hereunder shall be the same as those required in the present ordinances of the city, except that existing restaurants and nonconforming structures will be exempt from such requirements. 
(f)  Special qualifications for private clubs. Private clubs, as defined herein, shall furnish with license applications, a copy of the articles of incorporation from the State of Georgia, if incorporated by the state, and documentation of the valid up-to-date status of its national or state charter from its parent organization, together with documentation of its compliance denoting a tax-exempt status under Section 501 of the U.S. IRS Code. Private clubs whose primary purpose is not categorized by the term or terms "lodge," "fraternal order," or "veterans post," such as private clubs for golf, tennis and other similar recreation are exempt from the above provision which relates to a national or state charter from a parent organization. 
(g)  Completion of proposed licensed premises. Where a building in which a retailer intends to operate under the provisions of this section is at the time of the application for such license not in existence or not yet completed, a license may be issued for such location provided the plans for the proposed building show clearly a compliance with the other provisions of this section. No sales or consumption will be allowed in such establishment until it has been completed in accordance with said plans and is in conformity with all other provisions of this section and the City Code. 
(h)  Plot plan and floor plan to accompany application for new license. 
(1)  Each applicant for an original license, except private clubs, shall submit a plot plan and floor plan prepared by an architect, engineer, contractor, surveyor or other qualified person, showing all compliance with all distance, square foot, kitchen arrangement and food serving area table and seating arrangement requirements contained herein. 
(2)  On renewals, the same as the preceding shall be accomplished unless the applicant states in the reapplication that there has been no change in any of the above compliance items. 
(i)  Sale or delivery to unlicensed premises. It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverage by the drink beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. 
(j)  Exterior advertisements and media advertising prohibited. 
(1)  No signs of any kind, painted or electric, advertising any brand or price of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted on the exterior, or in the window of any licensed premises. No placard or sign or any kind which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of liquors sold therein. 
(2)  No outside signs of the any kind shall indicate that liquor by the drink is served within the licensed premises except that restaurants may add to the name of the business the words "and Lounge" onto any legal signs or advertising. 
(k)  Coin-operated devices; provisions. Coin-operated equipment is permitted on the premises for the following purposes: vending machines, such as cigarettes; vending a service, such as music or television; and for amusement, excluding any equipment designed or used for gambling purposes or refunds given in such manner as tickets, money or prizes to entice play. 
(l)  Package, broken package, carry-out sales prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell, or give or lend to any person, for any purpose, including carry-out, any alcoholic beverages by the package or bottle or by the broken container, or remainder, in a package or bottle. 
(m)  Service in back rooms prohibited. The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption by persons in any back room or side room which is not open to general public use is prohibited except that private parties or conventions, which have been scheduled in advance, may be served in public or private dining rooms or meeting rooms, and provided further that this prohibition shall not apply to private clubs hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-39. - Fingerprinting of beer, wine and liquor license applicants and certain employees; fees. 
(a)  Each applicant for a license to sell beer, wine, or liquor in the City of Cairo, who has not heretofore been licensed by the City of Cairo to sell beer, wine, or liquor at retail, shall be required to submit to a complete fingerprinting record and test, pursuant to the rules and regulations established by the city from time to time, the same being used by the city to supplement the information contained on the application and to make available to the city any records of criminal offenses, either federal or state, from other jurisdictions. 
(b)  The city manager, within his own discretion, from time to time, may require employees working in an establishment selling beer or wine to submit information for purposes of supplementing any information available to the city with respect to employees. Each such employee shall pay a ten-dollar ($10.00) fee for local records check and I.D. card to be worn while so employed. The city manager may require them to apply for complete fingerprinting for criminal history check within all provisions hereinafter as apply to employees of package liquor stores or liquor pouring establishments, and in the discretion of the city manager such additional fees as are reasonably related to recovery of the city's cost in time, equipment and material for such additional fingerprint search shall be charged. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 681, § 4, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 4-40. - Fingerprinting of certain persons affiliated with package liquor stores or liquor pouring establishments; procedure and eligibility provisions. 
(a)  Applicability; clearance. No person may work, except as in (b) below, in an establishment holding a license for sale of packaged liquor or for liquor pouring hereunder until such person has been fingerprinted by the police department and has been issued an I.D. card temporarily by the police department which shall indicate the person is eligible temporarily. 
(b)  Time limit. All persons subject to the provisions of this section shall, within three (3) days after the date of their first work in an establishment holding a license to sell alcoholic beverages, report to the city police department for purposes of being fingerprinted. 
(c)  Investigation and report. The city police department shall have a reasonable search made relative to any police record of the person fingerprinted. In the event there is no record of a violation of this chapter, such temporary issuance above shall become permanent unless cancelled. If it should be found there is a violation of this chapter by the person fingerprinted, the chief of police shall notify the licensee that such person is not eligible for continued work. No person shall continue working after receiving such notice of ineligibility. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee after receiving notification of the ineligibility of such worker to ensure that the worker ceases to work. 
(d)  Wearing of I.D. cards by all employees. The police department will furnish an identification card with picture for every worker of each licensed establishment, and every worker will publicly wear said identification card inside the business establishment at all times. The city manager may prescribe reasonable fees for certifying the eligibility for working. 
(e)  List of employees to be filed. It shall be the duty of all persons holding any license to sell alcoholic beverages to file with the chief of police the names of all employees, with their home addresses and home telephone numbers and places of employment. Changes in the list of employees, with the names of new employees, must be filed with the chief of police within three (3) days from the date of any such changes. 
(f)  Licensee responsible. The licensee is responsible for the conduct or actions of his employees while in his employ. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-41. - Use of persons with prior convictions; prohibited. 
No licensee shall work in any premises for the sale of alcoholic beverages any person in any capacity found to have been convicted of, or who shall have entered a plea of nolo contendere to, any felony within a period of ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of any such application, or to any misdemeanor within a period of five (5) years immediately prior to the filing of any such application, for any felony or misdemeanor of any state, or of the United States, or any municipal ordinance except a traffic violation. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond by a person charged with a crime. 
Notwithstanding the above provisions, the mayor and council, in its sole discretion, may direct the issuance of a letter of eligibility to persons who have in the past been convicted of, or plead guilty to, or entered a plea of nolo contendere, or forfeited a bond on any crime not involving force or violence, and the mayor and council after a thorough investigation of all the facts, including parole or probation officer's reports, judge's recommendations, and any other evidence bearing on the character of the applicant have determined that such action is in keeping with the public good and ends of justice, or the public interest and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-42. - Distance provisions relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages; allowable proximities to schools, churches, and residences. 
(a)  Special distance from residential property provisions. 
(1)  Package liquor, liquor pouring or beer and wine consumption on premises. No license hereunder shall be granted to any proposed location which is within fifty (50) feet of any private residence. The distance for the purpose of this section shall be measured in all directions from the nearest wall enclosing the proposed store where alcoholic beverages are to be sold to the nearest point of any residential property line, except that the provisions of this paragraph shall not apply on residences located adjacent to or in areas of the city zoned C-1 Neighborhood Commercial District, C-2 Highway Commercial District, CBD Central Business District, or C-PUD Commercial Planned Unit Development District. 
(2)  Private clubs. Distance requirements of subparagraph (a)(1) are not applicable for private clubs that were in operation prior to January 1, 1985, operating as a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Georgia as defined herein. 
(b)  General distance provisions. 
(1)  All beer and/or wine sales and liquor pouring sales; exceptions. No beer or wine or liquor pouring mixed drinks may be sold at any location within two hundred (200) yards of any school building, school grounds, college campus, or alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by any branch of government. The school building or educational building referred to herein shall apply only to state, county, city or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state are taught. No liquor pouring mixed drinks may be sold at any location within one hundred (100) yards of any church building. No beer or wine or liquor pouring mixed drinks may be sold at any location for consumption on the premises within one hundred (100) yards of any housing authority property. This subsection shall not apply at any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 2000, nor to the renewal of such license. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages within two hundred fifty (250) feet of any building within which such polling place is established on primary or election days. 
(2)  Packaged liquor sales. No packaged liquor may be sold at any location within one hundred (100) yards of any church building or an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by any branch of government, or within two hundred (200) yards of any school building or educational building. The school buildings or educational buildings referred to herein shall apply only to state, county, city or church school buildings and to private school buildings and to private school buildings in which subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state are taught. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages within two hundred fifty (250) feet of any building within which such polling place is established on primary or election days. No packaged liquor may be sold at any location for consumption on the premises within one hundred (100) yards of any housing authority property. 
a.  As used in the previous two (2) subsections, the term "housing authority property" means any property containing three hundred (300) housing units or fewer owned or operated by a housing authority created by Article 1 of Chapter 3 of Title 8, the "Housing Authorities Law." 
(3)  Exceptions to subparagraphs (b)(1) and (2) for the licensing of certain hotels or motels and certain private clubs. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the licensing of the sale of alcoholic beverages by: 
a.  Hotels or motels of fifty (50) guest rooms or more. 
b.  Bona fide private clubs licensed under the provisions for licensing liquor pouring in such clubs. 
(4)  Distance measurement methods. Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, all measurements to determine distances for the requirements of subparagraphs (b)(1) and (2) shall be measured by the most direct unimpeded route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: 
a.  From the front door of the structure from which alcoholic beverages are sold or offered for sale; 
b.  In a straight line to the nearest public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway; 
c.  Along such public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway by the nearest route; 
d.  To the front door of the building, or the nearest portion of the grounds, whichever is applicable to the language of subparagraphs (b)(1) and (2). 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 303, § 3, 7-16-86; Ord. No. 306, § 2, 8-11-86; Ord. No. 681, § 5, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 4-43. - Consumption-on-premises establishments. 
(a)  Off-street parking. The requirements of off-street parking for this section 4-43 shall be the same as would be required under the ordinances or codes for a new building, or under the zoning ordinances or codes for a new business. 
(b)  Visibility; shrubbery. On any premises occupied by a license holder hereunder, the immediate proximity of the building shall be maintained so as to keep vegetation low and vision unobstructed. Failure to comply with this provision shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of consumption-on-premises licenses, or denial or renewal of such licenses. 
(c)  Prohibited consumption on-premises. No licenses hereunder shall permit consumption of alcoholic beverages except inside portions of the building legal for such consumption. 
(d)  Premises to be well-lighted. The exterior of each building in which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises shall have sufficient lighting so that all entrances and parking areas are clearly visible at all times when the premises are open for business. Also, the lounge and restaurant areas, if any, and all tables, booths and other areas where customers are served, and all passageways for customers shall be sufficiently well-illuminated so that they may be viewed by those in such areas. 
(e)  Fire and safety; maximum occupancy provisions. All drinking establishments licensed or to be considered for licensing for consumption on the premises of any alcoholic beverages shall be measured as to the net usable floor area, and publicly visible posters stating the maximum number of persons allowable inside the building where such beverages are consumed shall be posted by the fire chief or assistant fire chief. The maximum allowable floor space per occupancy in the net usable floor area shall be fifteen (15) square feet. The alcoholic beverage licensee will be responsible for seeing that the established occupancy limits are not exceeded, and the violation of this provision shall be due cause for suspension or revocation by the mayor and council after proper hearing, of the alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Secs. 4-44—4-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX 
DIVISION 1. - MALT BEVERAGES 

Sec. 4-61. - Levied on wholesale dealers. 
(a)  Except as provided in paragraph (b) of this section, there is hereby levied and imposed upon all wholesale dealers selling malt beverages within the City of Cairo, Georgia, a specific excise tax computed on the basis of .4166 cents ($0.004166) per ounce or metric equivalent of malt beverages sold by each wholesale dealer within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo. 
(b)  All malt beverages sold in or from a barrel or bulk container and commonly known as tap or draft beer, shall not be subject to the excise tax provided for in paragraph (a) of this section, but in lieu thereof there is hereby levied and imposed upon each wholesale dealer selling such malt beverages within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo an excise tax of six dollars ($6.00) for each barrel or bulk container having a capacity of fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons or metric equivalent sold by such wholesale dealer within the City of Cairo and at a like rate for fractional parts thereof. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-62. - Monthly reports; payments. 
Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages within the City of Cairo shall file a report with the city clerk by the fifteenth day of each month showing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, sold by him within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the City of Cairo not later than the fifteenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with section 4-61. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-63. - Additional to other taxes or license fees. 
The excise tax provided for hereinabove shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages at wholesale within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-64. - Penalty and accrued interest on late reports and delinquent payments; city clerk to issue execution. 
The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten (10) per cent of the total amount due, plus interest accrued at the rate of twelve (12) per cent per annum. The clerk of the City of Cairo shall issue an execution against the said wholesale dealer, firm, or corporation so delinquent on his or its property, for the amount of the excise tax due and delinquent, plus penalty and interest accrued, and shall proceed to collect same in the same manner as is done in the case of executions issued for collection of city ad valorem property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-65. - False reports or nonpayment declared grounds for revocation of licenses of wholesale dealers of malt beverages. 
At any time it is found that false and fraudulent reports have been made by the wholesale dealer, his agents, officers, or employees, and upon which payment of malt beverages excise tax was reported or paid to the city, and at any time the monthly report and payment called for in section 4-62 is past due over thirty (30) days, the wholesale licensee shall be given not less than three (3) days nor more than ten (10) days notice of hearing before the mayor and council to show cause why his license to sell malt beverages in the City of Cairo should not be suspended or revoked because of such false and fraudulent reports, or nonpayment of taxes past due more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-66. - Sale of malt beverages upon which tax was not paid prohibited; penalties. 
It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to sell at retail or otherwise within the city, any malt beverage on which the tax as above set out has not been paid to the wholesaler for the city as above provided. In addition to the penalties provided for in section 9-3 of this Code, the violation of this article shall be deemed a sufficient ground for the revocation of the license of any retail or wholesale dealer holding a license or permit to sell malt beverages within the city. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
DIVISION 2. - WINE AND SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS 

Sec. 4-67. - Levied on retail dealers. 
There is hereby levied and imposed upon all retail dealers selling wine or spirituous liquors within the City of Cairo, Georgia, a specific excise tax computed on the basis of eighty-three cents ($0.83) per gallon or metric equivalent of wine or spirituous liquors sold by each retail dealer within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-68. - Collection, custody of taxes. 
At any time of delivery of wine or spirituous liquors to any retail dealer, the wholesaler shall collect from the retail dealer the excise taxes imposed in section 4-67 and hold the same in trust for the city until said tax is remitted to the city as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-69. - Additional to other taxes or license fees. 
The excise tax provided for hereinabove shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling at retail wine or spirituous liquors within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-70. - Invoices; required kept as records by wholesaler and retailer. 
Upon each and every delivery by a licensed wholesaler to a licensed retailer, an invoice in duplicate shall be prepared showing the number and size of each container of wine and spirituous liquors delivered, together with the price therefor and the excise taxes due and collected thereon. The original of such invoice shall be delivered by the wholesaler to the retailer simultaneously with such delivery, and the second copy of such invoice shall be retained by the wholesaler. Each retailer or wholesaler shall keep said invoices or copies for a period of twelve (12) months after the date of delivery, and during such twelve-month period, such invoices shall be made available for inspection by a representative of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-71. - Monthly reports; payments. 
Each wholesale dealer selling wines or spirituous liquors within the City of Cairo shall file a report with the city clerk by the fifteenth day of each month which shall correctly show the name of each retail dealer to whom a delivery was made during the preceding calendar month, the quantities of wine and spirituous liquors delivered to each dealer, the amount of excise tax collected under the terms of section 4-68, and such other reasonable information as may be required by the city. Said report shall be accompanied by remittance made payable to the City of Cairo for all taxes collected or due, as shown on said report. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-72. - Penalty and accrued interest on late reports and delinquent payments; city clerk to issue execution. 
The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten (10) per cent of the total amount due, plus interest accrued at the rate of twelve (12) per cent per annum. The clerk of the City of Cairo shall issue an execution against the said wholesale dealer, firm, or corporation so delinquent on his or its property, for the amount of the excise tax due and delinquent, plus penalty and interest accrued, and shall proceed to collect same in the same manner as is done in the case of executions issued for collection of city ad valorem property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-73. - Noncompliance herewith, false reports, or nonpayment declared grounds for revocation of licenses of wholesale dealers of wine and spirituous liquors. 
At any time it is found that a wholesale dealer has not complied with the terms imposed in this article, or that a wholesale dealer has made a false and fraudulent report to the city upon which excise taxes were reported or paid to the city, or at any time the monthly report and payment called for in section 4-71 is past due over thirty (30) days, the wholesale licensee shall be given not less than three (3) days nor more than ten (10) days notice of a hearing before the mayor and council to show cause why his license to sell wine or spirituous liquors in the City of Cairo should not be suspended or revoked because of such noncompliance, or false and fraudulent reports, or nonpayment of taxes past due more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Sec. 4-74. - Sale of wine or spirituous liquors upon which tax was not paid prohibited; penalties. 
It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to sell at retail or otherwise within this city, any wine or spirituous liquors on which the tax as above set out has not been paid to the wholesaler for the city as above provided. In addition to the penalties provided for in section 9-3 of this Code, the violation of this article shall be deemed a sufficient ground for the revocation of the license of any retail or wholesale dealer holding a license or permit to sell wine or spirituous liquors within the city. 
(Ord. No. 299, 5-5-86) 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Dead Animal Disposal Act, OCGA § 4-5-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Bird sanctuary—Area designated. 
The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(Code 1965, § 4-11) 
Sec. 5-2. - Same—Shooting, molesting, etc. 
No person shall trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl, or rob bird nests or wild fowl nests. 
(Code 1965, § 4-12) 
Sec. 5-3. - Same—Abatement of nuisances. 
(a)  If starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality as to constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property, in the opinion of the city health authorities, such health authorities shall meet with representatives of the Garden Club, after having given at least three (3) days actual notice of the time and place of such meeting to the representatives of the club. 
(b)  If, as a result of such meeting, no satisfactory alternative is found to abate the nuisance, the birds may be destroyed, in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by the health authorities, under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Code 1965, § 4-13) 
Sec. 5-4. - Livestock. 
Livestock shall only be kept or confined in areas of the city zoned for agricultural use (AG). Livestock including horses, mules, ponies, goats, donkeys, cows, sheep, hogs or other livestock within the city shall be located at least two hundred fifty (250) feet, strict measure, from any residence, other than that of the people owning the livestock, or business house, such measurement to be made from the nearest livestock enclosure wall to the nearest corner of the wall of the residence or business house. 
(Code 1965, §§ 4-31, 4-41, 4-52; Ord. No. 680, § 1, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 5-5. - Area requirements, fencing. 
Every enclosure for confining horses, mules, ponies, goats, donkeys, sheep, cows, hogs or other livestock shall be made secure by a fence of sufficient height to contain the animals and shall consist not less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet and shall contain no less than two thousand (2,000) square feet for each mule, horse, pony, goat, donkey, sheep, cow, hog or other livestock. Electric fences shall not be used. 
(Code 1965, §§ 4-32, 4-42, 4-53; Ord. No. 680, § 1, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 5-6. - Same—Sanitary condition. 
All enclosures for confining horses, mules, ponies, goats, donkeys, cows, hogs or other livestock, shall be maintained at all times in a clean and sanitary condition, subject to approval by the appropriate authorities of the city and county. 
(Code 1965, §§ 4-34, 4-44, 4-55; Ord. No. 680, § 1, 4-28-08) 
State Law reference— Rabies control, OCGA § 31-19-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-7. - Same—Removing animals when conditions become unsanitary. 
The officials of the city or county may order removal of all horses, mules, ponies, goats, donkeys, cows, hogs and other livestock, from any enclosure that becomes unsanitary upon ten (10) hours written notice to the owner or person in control thereof. 
(Code 1965, §§ 4-35, 4-45, 4-56; Ord. No. 680, § 1, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 5-8. - Livestock at large. 
No person shall leave any horse, mule or other livestock unhitched or unconfined so as to permit the running at large thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 4-51; Ord. No. 680, § 1, 4-28-08; Ord. No. 726, §§ 2, 3, 4-11-11) 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 726, adopted April 11, 2011, repealed former § 5-8 which pertained to fencing of domestic fowl, and derived from Ord. No. 136, adopted Aug. 5, 1968, and Ord. No. 680, adopted April 28, 2008. Section 3 of said ordinance renumbered former § 5-9 as § 5-8. 
State Law reference— Livestock at large, OCGA § 4-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-9. - Domestic fowl. 
Subject to the restrictions set forth herein related to domestic animals, the mayor and council establishes the following regulations regarding domestic fowl. Domestic fowl shall not be subject to the maximum number of animals set forth within section 5-26 entitled "Keeping of animals." 
The following domestic fowl are permitted within the City of Cairo: Chickens, ducks or geese. Roosters and pea fowl are excluded. Any residential lot shall be permitted to have no more than twenty-four (24) domestic fowl. Domestic fowl shall be confined by a substantial fence or pen. The perimeter or location of the fence or pen shall not be less than fifteen (15) feet from the property lines of all other residential lots or parcels occupied by adjacent property owners or their tenants or other persons in possession of the adjacent property. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 4, 4-11-11) 
Secs. 5-10, 5-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 278, adopted Aug. 13, 1984 provided for the repeal of §§ 4-19 and 4-20 of the 1965 Code, from which §§ 5-11 and 5-12 were derived. Said former sections pertained to bitches in heat running at large and the number of dogs permitted to be kept within the city. For current provisions relative to similar subject matter, see Art. II of this chapter. 
Secs. 5-12—5-23. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 402, § 1, adopted June 10, 1991, amended Art. II in its entirety by deleting former Art. II, §§ 5-24—5-33, and adding a new Art. II, §§ 5-24—5-39, to read as herein set forth. Prior to amendment, Art. II, §§ 5-24—5-33, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 359, § 1, adopted May 8, 1989. 

Sec. 5-24. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively attributed to them in this section. 
Abandoned animal. A domesticated animal which has been placed or found upon private or public property or roadways without the permission of the owner, tenant, or custodian of the property thereof, and left unattended and uncared for upon such property. An animal shall also be considered abandoned if it is retained upon the property of the owner or custodian without food and water for a period exceeding thirty-six (36) hours. 
Animal control officer. Any person designated by the mayor and council to enforce the provisions of this article. 
Animal control shelter. The facility designated by the mayor and council and/or any governmental unit with whom the city may have a contract for the detention or impoundment of animals. 
City is the City of Cairo, a municipality and the entire area embraced in the corporate limits of the City of Cairo, Georgia. 
Domesticated animal. An animal that is accustomed to live in and about the habitation of the population, including but not limited to fowl, cats, dogs, cows, horses, swine, sheep, and goats. 
Guard dog. A dog which has been trained to attack persons or other animals independently or upon command or any dog, while not so trained, which reasonably is expected to perform as a guardian of the property upon which he or she is located. 
Humane manner. Care of a domestic animal to include, but not be limited to, adequate heat, ventilation and sanitary shelter, or manner of restraint, wholesome food and water, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species, and breed. 
Owner. Any person, firm, corporation, organization or department possessing, harboring or having the care or custody whether temporarily or permanently of a domesticated animal for a period of seventy-two (72) hours or more. 
Restraint. An animal is "under restraint" within the meaning of this article if it is (1) controlled by a leash, (2) at "heel" or accompanying a competent person and obedient to that person's commands (under verbal control of owner or other person), (3) on or within a vehicle driven or parked on the streets, and (4) within the property limits of its owner. 
Untagged animal. An animal is considered to be untagged if a valid license tag is not attached to a collar which is kept on the animal. 
Vicious animals. Any animal which constitutes a physical threat to human beings or other domesticated or wild animals by virtue of attacking or biting a person or other animal without provocation shall be deemed a vicious animal. This definition shall not be deemed to include any activity which is permitted under the game laws of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 653, § 1, 2-14-07) 
Sec. 5-25. - Agreement with other governmental unit. 
The mayor and council may enter into a contractual agreement with any governmental unit of Grady County to provide animal control services with the city. No such contract may be entered into until such governmental unit may have available those facilities that may be required under this article and such unit have in effect any animal control ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 5-26. - Keeping of animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit an animal under his ownership, possession, control or care to be a nuisance as defined herein or under restraint as set forth within this article within the city. An animal shall be deemed to be a nuisance for the following reasons: 
(1)  Lack of proof of current rabies vaccination. 
(2)  Biting of person or animal. 
(3)  Upon request by law enforcement agency or health department following investigation and determination that an animal is a nuisance or vicious as defined herein. 
Except for a person in an occupation requiring or involving the keeping of animals located within areas permitted by City of Cairo zoning regulations, no person shall be allowed to keep more than four (4) animals at any location. Puppies and kittens less than ten (10) weeks shall be excluded. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 5-27. - Vicious animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, organization or department to possess or maintain within the city any animal that is vicious unless such animal is confined and secured upon the property of the owner or other person having custody of such animal in such a manner as would prohibit such animal from molesting, attacking or biting any person or other animal. Such animal shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or structure suitable to prevent the injury of young children, and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Such pen or structure must have a minimum dimension of five (5) feet by ten (10) feet and must have secure sides and a secure top. If it has no bottom secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded into the ground no less than two (2) feet. The enclosure must also provide protection from the elements for the animal. 
The owner or keeper shall display a sign on his or her premises facing out from all sides of the premises warning that there is a dangerous animal on the property. This sign should be visible and capable of being read from a public highway or thoroughfare within twenty (20) feet of its placement. 
A vicious animal may be off the owner's premises only if it is muzzled and restrained by an approved lead or chain not exceeding three (3) feet in length and is under the control of an adult who is an able-bodied person. The muzzle must be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but must prevent it from biting any person or animal. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 653, § 2, 2-14-07) 
Sec. 5-28. - Guard dogs. 
It shall be the duty of the owner, tenant or custodian of any residential property on which a guard dog or security dog is kept for security purposes to post a notice in a prominent and conspicuous location on such property. Such notice shall comprise the words "WARNING—GUARD DOG" and shall be in clearly distinguishable block letters upon a background of clearly contrasting color. Such letters shall not be less than one (1) inch in width and not less than five (5) inches in height. Further, the owner, tenant or custodian shall post the universal symbol for guard/dangerous dog in a prominent and conspicuous location on such property. If a guard dog is confined within a fenced area, such notice shall be conspicuously posted upon such fence at every entrance and exit of the fence. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 5-29. - Identification and inoculation. 
Identification. Any person owning a vicious animal shall on or before April 1, 2007 and annually thereafter on or before April 1 of each year register that animal and provide a current color photograph of that animal with the office of clerk of the city and pay a registration fee in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00). At the time of registration, each owner of any dangerous animal within the limits of the City of Cairo shall provide to the clerk proof of liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any acts of property damage or liability incurred by virtue of injury inflicted by such animal. Such insurance shall name the city as a coinsured solely for the purpose of notice of cancellation of the policy. Upon payment of the fee, the city clerk shall issue a current dangerous dog collar of an approved color for the purpose of identification and which color is to be worn by the dog at all times as proof of registration. If when due to the length of the dog's hair, the color is not visible, an approved colored lead or chain shall be used. 
Inoculation. Every owner custodian of an animal that is four (4) months of age or older within the city shall have such animal vaccinated for rabies, if required by law. It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess or maintain any animal that does not have a current rabies inoculation and such animal shall at all times wear a securely attached collar about its neck or harness that shall have attached thereto a current rabies tag. 
[Violation.] Any person failing to identify or inoculate the animal shall be guilty of violation of this section and be subject to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 653, § 4, 2-14-07) 
Sec. 5-30. - Impoundment of animals. 
Any animal that shall be a public nuisance or is not under restraint as defined herein or otherwise in violation of this article, whether or not the animal is on private or public property, shall be impounded by the designated animal control officers in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 5-31. - Redemption of impounded animal. 
It shall be the duty of the designated animal control officers to notify the owner, if known or can be reasonably ascertained, of every animal impounded, by telephone or by mail. If no owner can be ascertained, the animal will be held for three (3) days before being destroyed unless other arrangements have been made. Following notification, the animal will be held for three (3) days. Thereafter, the animal may be destroyed or placed for adoption. Before release, the owner must provide proof of current rabies vaccination or pay for rabies vaccination before release. No animal will be released without proper rabies protection or necessary arrangements made for rabies inoculation. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 5-32. - Fees. 
The fees to be paid before an animal is retrieved by owner shall be established by resolution of mayor and council. The following fees are established upon the adoption of this section: 

 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91; Ord. No. 653, § 3, 2-14-07) 
Sec. 5-33. - Adoption. 
The designated animal control officers are authorized to offer for adoption any animal that has been impounded and unclaimed by the owner or has been delivered to the division. 
Any animal that is eligible for adoption may be offered after three (3) days from the date of impoundment if the owner should be unknown or within three (3) days of notice to the owner if the owner shall be known. The party desiring the animal shall pay the impoundment fee and one (1) day boarding fee as an adoption fee and the cost of rabies inoculation if the animal is not displaying a current rabies inoculation tag. 
(Ord. No. 402, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 5-34. - Disposition of unclaimed animals.
