(4)  Any person released under subsection (3) above shall receive a receipt for any driver's license deposited or, if released on the person's own recognizance, shall sign and receive a copy of the citation or ticket describing the violation for which the person was arrested. 
(5)  All persons arrested or notified by citation or ticket of parking violations shall be released on their own recognizance. 
(Code 1965, § 26-19; Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-14. - Forfeiture of appearance bonds. 
(a)  The municipal judge or the judge's designee shall call the case in its regular order, and, if the accused is not in court and does not answer the call, and, if no good and sufficient reason is given for nonappearance, the judge shall enter on the docket where the case is stated "Bond forfeited," or similar words. 
(b)  Upon forfeiture of any bond, the cash deposited as security shall be paid to the city clerk, and it shall become the property of the city. 
(c)  Upon the forfeiture of any bond signed by a person as surety, the city clerk shall issue an execution against the principal and surety on the bond for the amount thereof which shall be collected as tax executions are collected. 
(Code 1965, § 26-20; Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-15. - Pleas. 
(a)  Upon a case being called, the municipal judge shall inform the defendant of the charge against such defendant and shall inquire as to how such defendant desires to plead thereon. Thereupon, the defendant shall enter one of the following pleas: 
(1)  Guilty; 
(2)  Not guilty; 
(3)  Nolo contendere (with the permission of the court); or 
(4)  A former judgment of conviction or acquittal of the offense charged. 
(b)  If the defendant refuses to enter a plea, the court shall enter a plea of not guilty and set the case down for trial. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-16. - Continuance of cases. 
The municipal judge may refuse to continue a case, except for good cause shown. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-17. - Appearance of complaining witnesses. 
A material or complaining witness in any contested prosecution shall appear at the session at which the prosecution is docketed. The prosecution may be dismissed if the material witness fails to appear. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-18. - Judgment and sentences. 
Upon a judgment or plea of guilty the court shall impose sentence. The court may: 
(1)  Impose a fine, with or without a commitment for confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(2)  Commit the defendant to confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(3)  Suspend the execution of the sentence in whole or in part; 
(4)  Defer the execution of the sentence or any portion or portions thereof to one or more fixed dates in the future; or 
(5)  Impose such other form of judgment or sentence as the court deems appropriate, including but not limited to emotional maturity training, driver education, and to probate or suspend any of the foregoing sentences upon such conditions as the court shall deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Cross reference— General penalty, § 1-8. 
Sec. 9-19. - Enforcement of fines by levy and execution; payment in advance of court date. 
(a)  For fines that may be due by any defendant, execution may be issued by the city clerk and collected as tax executions are collected. 
(b)  Persons charged with traffic violations may, prior to the time for their court appearance, plead guilty in writing and pay to the city as their fine the amount set as the appearance bond for the offense charged; except that those persons charged with driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs and those charged with an offense in connection with an automobile collision shall be required in all cases to appear before the court for disposition of the case. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-20. - Contempt of court. 
Failure to appear pursuant to any summons or subpoena, disrespectful conduct or failure to comply with any other order or judgment of the court shall constitute contempt of court and be punishable as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Sec. 9-21. - Court dates; contempt warrants; appeals. 
(a)  Court date will be made known to the defendant at the time of the arrest process and shall be properly indicated on the copy of charges given to the defendant by the arresting officer. 
(b)  Warrants for contempt of court charges may be issued following each session of court. 
(c)  Appeals may be taken from the municipal court in accordance with applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 255, § 3, 6-29-82) 
Chapter 10 - FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Occupational license taxes, Ch. 14. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Fiscal year; budget year. 
(a)  The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the first day of July and end on the thirtieth day of June. 
(b)  The fiscal year shall constitute the budget year of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 11-12) 
Secs. 10-2—10-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUDGET 

Sec. 10-20. - Nature and scope. 
(a)  The budget of the city shall present a complete financial plan for the ensuing budget year. 
(b)  The budget shall set forth: 
(1)  All proposed expenditures for the administration, operation and maintenance of all offices, departments, boards, commissions and activities, including publicly owned and operated utilities and enterprises. 
(2)  The actual or estimated operating deficits from prior years. 
(3)  All interest and debt redemption charges during the budget year. 
(4)  Expenditures for capital projects to be undertaken or executed during the budget year, including expenditures for local improvements which may be paid for in whole or in part by special assessments. 
(5)  The anticipated income and other means of financing the proposed expenditures for the fiscal year. 
(Code 1965, § 11-13) 
Sec. 10-21. - Budget document. 
The budget document shall consist of three (3) parts, the nature and contents of which shall be as follows: 
(1)  Part I shall consist of a budget message prepared by the city manager which shall outline the fiscal policy of the city for the fiscal year, describing in connection therewith the important features of the budget plan; it shall also embrace a general budget summary setting forth the aggregate figures of the budget in such manner as to show the balanced relations between the total proposed expenditures and the total anticipated income and other means of financing the budget for the ensuing fiscal year, contrasted with the corresponding figures for the last completed fiscal year and the year in progress. The general budget summary shall be supported by explanatory schedules or statements, classifying the expenditures contained therein by organization units, sources and funds. 
(2)  Part II shall contain the detailed budget estimates both of expenditures and revenues as provided for in section 10-20. It shall also include statements of the bonded indebtedness of the city showing the debt redemption requirements, the debt authorized and unissued, the condition of any sinking funds, and the borrowing capacity; in addition thereto, it shall contain any statements relative to the financial plan which the city manager may deem desirable or which may be required by the governing body. 
(3)  Part III shall contain complete drafts of the budget ordinances; that is, the ordinances required to give legal sanction to the financial plan when adopted by the governing body. These ordinances shall include an appropriation ordinance, authorizing by spending agencies and funds, all expenditures of the city for budget year; and such other ordinances as may be required to provide the income necessary to finance the budget. 
(Code 1965, § 11-14) 
Sec. 10-22. - Preparation. 
At least sixty (60) days prior to the beginning of the fiscal year, all departments, offices, boards and other spending agencies of the city shall prepare and submit to the city manager estimates of their expenditure requirements and their estimated revenues for the forthcoming budget year, compared with the corresponding figures of the last completed fiscal year and the estimated figures for the year in progress. The expenditure estimates shall be classified to set forth the data by funds, organizations, units, character, and objects of expenditure; the organization units may be subclassified by functions and activities at the discretion of the city manager. The revenue estimates shall be classified so as to show the receipts by funds, organization units and sources of income. 
(1)  The city manager shall review the estimates, altering, revising, increasing or decreasing the items of such estimates as such officer shall deem necessary in view of the needs of the various spending agencies and the probable income of the city. The city manager shall then prepare a budget in the form required by the provisions of section 10-21. 
(2)  The city manager shall transmit the budget to the governing body at least thirty (30) days before the beginning of the fiscal year. 
(Code 1965, § 11-15) 
Cross reference— Budget year, § 10-1. 
Sec. 10-23. - Hearing; publication of budget prior to hearing. 
(a)  Final action shall not be taken on the proposed budget until at least one public hearing has been held thereon after ten (10) days' notice thereof. 
(b)  The governing body shall arrange for and hold such hearing. 
(c)  The budget, when submitted by the city manager to the governing body, shall be published, advertised or otherwise made available for public inspection at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Code 1965, § 11-16) 
Sec. 10-24. - Adoption of budget ordinance. 
At least one (1) week after the conclusion of the hearing required in section 10-23, the governing body shall consider the budget as submitted to it by the city manager and shall adopt a budget ordinance making appropriations in such sums as the governing authority may deem sufficient, whether greater or less than the sums presented in the proposed budget. The budget ordinance shall be adopted at a public meeting which shall be advertised at least one week prior to the meeting. 
(Code 1965, § 11-17; Ord. No. 718, § 1, 6-14-10) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 718, adopted June 14, 2010, changed the title of § 10-24 from "Adoption; publication of budget summary after adoption" to "Adoption of budget ordinance." 
Sec. 10-25. - Appropriations—Form. 
(a)  The appropriation ordinance, provided for in section 10-21, shall be drawn in such form as to authorize only lump sum appropriations to meet the expenditure needs of the various spending agencies of the municipal government. 
(b)  For the operation and maintenance expenses of each department, office, board or other spending agency, there shall be a single appropriation, which shall be allotted as provided in section 10-29 before becoming available for expenditure. 
(c)  Appropriations for the acquisition of property shall be in such detail under each spending agency as the city manager shall determine; provided, however, that such appropriations shall not be segregated into greater detail than the major classes, or projects, for which they are expendable. 
(Code 1965, § 11-18) 
Sec. 10-26. - Same—Effect of failure to make. 
If at the termination of any fiscal year, the appropriations necessary for the support of the municipal government of the city for the ensuing fiscal year shall not have been made, the several amounts appropriated in the last appropriation ordinance for the objects and purposes therein specified, so far as the same shall relate to the operation and maintenance expenses, shall be deemed to be reappropriated for the several objects and purposes specified in the last appropriation ordinance; and until the governing body shall act in such behalf, the treasurer shall make the payments necessary for the support of the municipal government on the basis of the appropriations of the preceding fiscal year. 
(Code 1965, § 11-19) 
Sec. 10-27. - Same—Additional. 
The governing body may, during a fiscal year, make additional appropriations or increase existing appropriations to meet emergencies. The funds therefor shall be provided from unappropriated revenues, if any, or from temporary loans. Such temporary loans shall be repaid at an annual rate equivalent to not less than two (2) mills upon the assessed valuation of real property within the city. 
(Code 1965, § 11-20) 
Sec. 10-28. - Same—Transfer. 
The governing body may authorize the transfer within the same fund of any unencumbered appropriation balance or any portion thereof from one spending agency under its jurisdiction to another. Such action shall be taken only on the recommendation of the city manager, and only during the last six (6) months of the fiscal year. 
(Code 1965, § 11-21) 
Sec. 10-29. - Allotments. 
(a)  Immediately before the beginning of the fiscal year, the city manager shall require the head of each spending agency to submit a work program for the budget year, which program shall include all appropriations for operation and maintenance expenditures and for the acquisition of property. Such work program shall show the requested allotments and appropriations for such spending agency by months for the entire year. 
(b)  The city manager shall review the requested allotments in the light of the work program of the spending agency concerned, and shall, if deemed necessary, revise, alter or change such allotments before approving them. 
(c)  The aggregate of such allotments shall not exceed the total appropriations available to the spending agency for the budget year. 
(d)  The city manager shall transmit copies of the approved allotments to the head of the spending agency concerned and to the city treasurer. 
(e)  The treasurer shall authorize all expenditures to be made from the appropriations on the basis of such allotments, and not otherwise. 
(f)  The head of any spending agency of the municipal government, whenever such head shall deem it necessary by reason of changed conditions, may revise the work program of such person's agency at the beginning of any month during the budget year and submit such revised program to the city manager with a request for a revision of the allotments for the remaining months of the budget year. If, upon a re-examination of the work program, the city manager shall grant the request for a revision of the allotments, the same procedure, so far as it relates to review, approval and control, shall be followed as in making the original allotments. 
(g)  In order to provide funds for possible emergencies arising during the budget year in the operation and maintenance expenditures of the various spending agencies of the municipal government, the city manager may require the head of each spending agency, in making the original allotments, to set aside at least five (5) per cent of the total amount appropriated as a reserve. At any time during the budget year, this reserve, or any portion of it, may be returned to the appropriation to which it belongs and be added to any one or more of the allotments, provided the city manager shall deem such action necessary, and shall notify the city treasurer of such action. Any unused portion thereof shall remain at the end of the budget period as an unexpended balance of appropriation. 
(Code 1965, § 11-22) 
Sec. 10-30. - When contracts and expenditures prohibited. 
(a)  No officer, employee or agent of the city shall expend or contract to be expended any money or incur any liability, or enter into any contract which, by its terms, involves the expenditure of money for any purposes for which provision is made in the appropriation ordinance in excess of the amounts appropriated in such ordinance for that fiscal year. 
(b)  Any contract, verbal or written, made in violation of this section shall be null and void as an obligation of the city, and no moneys belonging to the city shall be paid thereon; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prevent the making of contracts for governmental services for a period exceeding one year, but any contract so made shall be executory only for the amounts agreed to be paid for such services to be rendered in succeeding fiscal years. 
(Code 1965, § 11-23) 
Chapter 11 - FIRE PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Fireworks, OCGA, § 25-10-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - State safety rules and regulations—Adopted by reference. 
(a)  The rules and regulations promulgated for the prevention of destruction of life and property by fire, explosion and related hazards in the state by the state safety fire commissioner, under authority of the powers vested in and duties imposed upon the safety fire commissioners by the laws of the state, are hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)  All rules and regulations of this city, and all rules and regulations heretofore adopted in conflict with the rules and regulations adopted by subsection (a) are hereby repealed. 
(Code 1965, § 12-19) 
State Law reference— Promulgation of rules and regulations, OCGA, § 25-2-4. 
Sec. 11-2. - Same—Cooperation with state official for enforcement. 
The city fire marshal and all other city officials, department heads and employees shall co-operate with the state safety fire commissioner and state fire marshal and their deputies or assistants in the enforcement of the state safety fire law, and the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto and adopted by section 11-1. 
(Code 1965, § 12-20) 
Sec. 11-3. - Gasoline trucks with trailers prohibited on certain streets. 
No person shall operate or cause to be operated any transport truck with a semi-trailer, or a transport truck with a trailer, hauling gasoline or kerosene on certain streets and avenues in the city as follows: 
(1)  Broad Street, from Third Avenue, North, to Third Avenue South. 
(2)  First Avenue, N.E., from Fifth Street, N.E., to North Broad Street. 
(Code 1965, § 12-1) 
Sec. 11-4. - Registration of burning. 
(a)  All citizens are required to advise the Cairo Fire Department of deliberate burns within the City of Cairo. 
(b)  No person shall burn trash, paper, or other rubbish within the city. Natural vegetation consisting of a six-foot by six-foot area or less may be burned after having first obtained the necessary permission from the Cairo Fire Department. Requests for permission to burn areas of natural vegetation greater than six-foot by six-foot shall be directed to the office of the city fire chief. 
(c)  Failure to register a burn that shall be deliberate shall result in punishment as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 669, § 1, 8-27-07; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 4-28-08; Ord. No. 749, § 1, 10-14-13) 
Sec. 11-5. - Open burning—Permits and fees. 
(a)  Permits for open burning at or on development sites for the purpose of clearing land for new construction shall be obtained from the office of the city fire chief. 
(b)  The applicant shall complete an application for an open burning permit issued by the fire department. The applicant shall submit a plat or site plan showing the proposed location of the pit and information relating to the proximity of any occupied or unoccupied structure. 
(c)  No burning shall commence prior to an inspection of the site and the pit by a representative of the fire department. Upon approval of the pit, the permit shall be valid for a period of thirty (30) days; the permit can be cancelled at anytime during this period due to weather. Permits may be extended for increments of fifteen-day periods, maximum of two (2) extensions. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 2, 10-14-13) 
Sec. 11-6. - Fires requiring written permits. 
(a)  The only type of fires permitted for the purpose of land clearing is pit fires. Nonpit fires are not permitted for land clearing within the city limits. All pit fires shall be conducted in strict accordance with the "Air Curtain Destructor Operating Guide and Procedures," as published by the Environmental Protection Division. 
(b)  Pit fires shall comply with the following stipulations: 
(1)  The pit shall be at least three hundred (300) feet from any occupied or habitable structure. This distance may be decreased upon determination by the fire department. 
(2)  Where a site cannot be excavated to the recommended depth due to high water table and/or subsurface rock, the pit may be constructed above ground level, subject to the same state standards and procedures for a pit below ground level. 
(3)  Only wood wastes consisting of trees, logs, large brush, stumps, leaves, and untreated lumber may be burned in the pit. 
(4)  Leaves, sawdust or other densely packed wood wastes, paper (any type), chemically treated, coated or impregnated wood, or nonwood construction materials shall not be burned. The amount of dirt/soil mixture shall be kept to a minimum. 
(5)  No more than one (1) air curtain destructor is allowed to be operated within a ten-acre permitted site at one (1) time. The air curtain destructor must be under the supervision of a trained operator at all times during operation. If there is a need for multiple burning pits, there shall be a minimum of one thousand (1,000) feet between each burning pit. 
(6)  Air curtain destructors shall be able to pass an even, nonturbulent flow of air across the top of the pit. Air curtain destructors with an air duct or manifold that has been altered by bends, dents, holes, etc., and are incapable of providing an even and nonturbulent flow of air across the top of the pit shall not be approved for use. 
(7)  The air curtain destructor shall be operated in a manner to prevent air, land or water pollution, safety/health hazards or nuisances. 
(8)  Tires or other rubber products, plastics, heavy oils or asphaltic base or impregnated materials shall not be used to start or maintain air curtain destructor operations. 
(9)  When the pit is cleared of ash, airborne particulate is to be minimized by wetting or mixing the ashes with dirt. 
(10)  Diesel fuel or kerosene only may be used to start pit fires. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 3, 10-14-13) 
Sec. 11-7. - Burning restrictions. 
The following rules govern all burning within the city limits, whether or not a written permit is required: 
(1)  The fire chief's office may temporarily prohibit any and/or all outdoor fires when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous. 
(2)  No burning of solid waste or household garbage is allowed. 
(3)  No burning of any materials that emit a heavy dark smoke, such as rubber products, oils, roofing material, petroleum based products, etc., is allowed. 
(4)  All fires shall be constantly attended by a competent person until extinguished. 
(5)  There shall be a garden hose connected to a water supply or other fire extinguishing equipment readily available for use. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 4, 10-14-13) 
Sec. 11-8. - Summary abatement. 
The staff of the fire chief's office and personnel of the fire department shall have the authority to summarily abate any conditions which are in violation of any of the provisions of this article, and which may constitute an immediate threat to life and property. In no event shall a pit fire or other open burning continue after the fire chief's office has revoked the permit. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 5, 10-14-13) 
Secs. 11-9—11-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 11-20. - Fire Prevention and Safety Code adopted by reference. 
There is hereby adopted by reference as fully and to the same extent as if set out at length herein, subject to all amendments and conflicting provisions contained in the Code of Ordinances, those certain published codes known as the Fire Prevention Code for Buildings and NFPA Life Safety Code, editions most currently adopted by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, one (1) copy of each being on file at the office of the building official which shall be the official copy of said code. 
(Ord. No. 334, § 11, 9-26-88; Ord. No. 440, § 20, 12-12-94; Ord. No. 749, § 6, 10-14-13) 
Editor's note— Section 11 of Ord. No. 334, adopted Sept. 26, 1988, added Art. XII, Fire Prevention, § 6-210, to Ch. 6. At the discretion of the editor, for purposes of classification, the provisions of said § 11 of Ord. No. 334 have been treated as superseding § 11-20 and have been codified as new § 11-20 herein. Former § 11-20 adopted the Fire Prevention Code, 1981 edition, by reference, and was derived from Code 1965, § 12-8; and Ord. No. 141, § 1, adopted Jan. 13, 1969. 
Sec. 11-21. - Establishment of special districts. 
The limits referred to in the fire prevention code restricting storage of flammable liquids and explosives are hereby established as follows: First and second fire zones of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 12-10) 
Note— See the editor's note to § 6-4 of Ch. 6 of this Code. 
Sec. 11-22. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the building official or such official's designated agents. 
(Code 1965, § 12-11) 
Sec. 11-23. - Modifications. 
(a)  The building official may modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or such owner's or lessee's duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. 
(b)  The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the building official thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished to the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 12-12) 
Sec. 11-24. - Appeals. 
Whenever the building official or fire chief shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of such code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the building official or fire chief to the governing body within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed from. 
(Code 1965, § 12-13; Ord. No. 749, § 7, 10-14-13) 
Chapter 12 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Sanitary condition of livestock enclosure, § 5-7. 
State Law reference— Authority as to health generally, OCGA § 36-34-4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 405, § 1, adopted Aug. 8, 1991, amended the Code by deleting former § 12-1, which pertained to littering with handbills on private or public property and derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 2.3-1, 2.3-2; redesignating former §§ 12-2—12-4 as §§ 12-5—12-7; and adding new §§ 12-1—12-4, as herein set forth. 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply within this chapter: 
Litter means all sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste material, tin and aluminum cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals, abandoned appliances, or discarded materials of every kind and description. 
Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse; any park, playground, building, refuge or conservation or recreation area; residential or agricultural property, or wooded area. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 12-2. - Dumping, depositing, etc., litter on public or private property or waters. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, deposit, throw or leave or cause to permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property within the city or waters within the city unless: 
(1)  The property is designated by the city for the disposal of litter and the person is authorized by proper city authorities to use such property; 
(2)  The litter is placed into a litter receptacle or container installed on such property; or 
(3)  The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare and applicable state and federal regulation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to place, throw down, deposit or leave any circular, dodger, advertising matter including political campaign material, or other written or printed commercial, business or mercantile information, either on paper or on other material used for advertising or information purposes, on any of the public areas, city property including but not limited to utility poles, traffic signs and signals, benches and trash containers, streets, sidewalks or alleys of the city, or on the lawn, yard or grounds of any private owner located in the city except with the permission of the owner or legal occupant thereof; provided however as to private property this section shall not apply to the normal and usual delivery of daily newspaper by the carrier thereof. These provisions shall also apply to any person who counsels or commands the violation of said subsection by the person who as principal actually and physically commits the violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 12-3. - Penalties for violation of litter ordinance. 
Any person who violates section 12-1 shall be punished as set forth in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances. Further, (1) in the sound discretion of the court in which conviction is obtained, a person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of the sentence, or (2) in the sound discretion of the judge of the court in which conviction is obtained a person may be directed to pick up or remove from any public park, private right-of-way or with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of the sentence. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 12-4. - Prima facie evidence; rebuttable presumption. 
(a)  Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane or other conveyance in violation of section 12-1, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated section 12-1. 
(b)  Except as provided within this chapter, whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this chapter it is discovered to contain any article or articles, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications or other writings which display the name of the person thereon in which manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated Section 12-1 herein. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 12-5. - Burning of trash. 
(a)  No person shall burn trash, paper, or other rubbish within the city. Natural vegetation consisting of a six-foot by six-foot area or less may be burned after having first obtained the necessary permission from the Cairo Fire Department. Requests for permission to burn areas of natural vegetation greater than six-foot by six-foot shall be directed to the office of the city fire chief. 
(b)  Such person who violates the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 14-1; Ord. No. 361, § 1, 8-14-89; Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91; Ord. No. 685, § 1, 4-28-08; Ord. No. 750, § 1, 10-14-13) 
State Law reference— Air Quality Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-9-1 et seq. 
Sec. 12-6. - Noise—General prohibition. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessarily or unusually loud noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others, within the city. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 12-7. - Same—Specific prohibitions; exemptions. 
(a)  Prohibited noises: The following acts among others are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this Code, but said enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, or other vehicle on any street or public place in the city, except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. The use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. 
(2)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any radio or television set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast on the public streets for the purpose of advertising or for attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. 
(3)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or any other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(4)  Exhaust. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any internal combustion engine, motor boat or any other motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(5)  Vehicles out of repair, etc. The use of any automobile, motorcycle, motorscooter, go-cart, or any other vehicle so out of repair, or so loaded or in such a manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling, or other noise, including excessive noise coming through the exhaust thereof. 
(b)  Exemptions: The following uses and activities shall be exempt from noise level regulations: 
(1)  Noises of safety signals, warning devices and emergency pressure relief valves. 
(2)  Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in the time of an emergency. 
(3)  Any other noise resulting from activities of temporary duration permitted by law and for which a license or permit has been granted by the city in accordance with its ordinances and laws. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Secs. 12-8—12-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNSANITARY AND UNSIGHTLY CONDITIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 673, adopted Jan. 28, 2007, enacted provisions designated as §§ 12-20—12-28, and have been treated as superseding §§ 12-20—12-32, which pertained to unfit buildings or structures, abandoned/junked vehicles, unsafe and unsanitary conditions and derived from Ord. No. 519, § 1, adopted July 26, 1999; Ord. No. 545, § 1, adopted Nov. 13, 2000; and Ord. No. 589, § 1, adopted April 28, 2003. 

Sec. 12-20. - Findings; policy. 
(a)  It is found that in the city there exist unsafe, unsanitary and unsightly conditions related to abandoned or junk vehicles, appliances, furniture, household goods and materials and unkept or unmowed areas. 
(b)  It is the policy of the city to investigate and determine the existence of unsafe, unsanitary and unsightly conditions generally within the city so as to prevent conditions that are dangerous or injurious to the health of the citizens and deleterious to property values. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Sec. 12-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned/junk motor vehicles means any vehicle designed to be self-propelled or towed for travel upon the ground including but not limited to automobiles, buses, motorcycles, trucks, tractors, go-carts, campers or trailers that shall not have affixed thereto unexpired license plates or tags or is [are] currently registered with the Georgia Department of Motor Vehicles and is [are] in a wrecked, dismantled, inoperative or abandoned condition. 
City manager means the city manager of the City of Cairo, Georgia, or his designated agent. 
Nuisance or junk material means household appliances, construction material, trash, furniture, or furnishings of any nature that shall be in an unsafe or unsanitary condition. 
Nuisance vegetation means: 
(1)  Vegetation that obstructs the safe view of traffic at an intersection or driveway. 
(2)  Dead or dying trees or plants that may cause a hazard or damage a structure if they fall. 
(3)  Vegetation that consists of plants that regenerate annually being classified as weeds that exceed an average height of eighteen (18) inches that are the predominate cover [of] more than one-fourth (¼) of a lot or property located within two hundred (200) feet of a building used for residential, commercial, industrial purposes. 
Public official means any city employee who is in charge of any department of the city or the state relating to health, fire, streets, parks or building regulations or other activities concerning dwellings, buildings or structures or health conditions in the city. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Sec. 12-22. - Procedures relating to the removal of abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation. 
(a)  The city manager shall be designated as the public officer to exercise the powers as set forth in this article. 
(b)  Whenever a request is filed with the city manager by a public official or by at least three (3) residents of the city charging that there exists abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation on any private property within the city, or whenever it appears to the city manager (on his own motion) that abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation exist within the city, the city manager may, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and any party having an interest in said property containing such material or condition, a notice stating that a hearing will be held before the city manager at a place within the city fixed not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days after the serving of said complaint; that the owner and any parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appeal in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the complaint; and that the rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the city manager. 
(c)  If, after such notice and hearing the city manager determines that the property under consideration does contain abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation, he shall state in writing his findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner and any party having an interest in said property an order stating that within the time specified in the order, being not more than thirty (30) days, the abandoned/junk motor vehicles, or nuisance or junk material shall be removed or the nuisance vegetation shall be cut. 
(d)  If the owner fails to comply with any order to remove the abandoned/junk motor vehicles, or nuisance or junk material or cut the nuisance vegetation, the city manager may cause such motor vehicle or nuisance or junk material to be removed or nuisance vegetation to be cut; provided, however, that this action shall not be exercised until the city council shall have approved by resolution the action to be taken. 
(e)  The amount of the cost of such removal of the material or cutting of the vegetation by the city manager shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. Such lien shall attach to the real property upon the payment of all costs of removal or cutting by the city and the filing of an itemized statement of the total sum of such costs by the city manager in the office of the clerk of the City of Cairo on a lien docket maintained by the clerk for such purposes. Such lien may be recorded on the lien docket of Grady County, Georgia, at the option of the clerk of the City of Cairo. If any item or material removed may be sold by the city manager, he shall sell same and shall credit the proceeds of such sale against the cost of the removal and/or cleaning of the property and any balance remaining shall be deposited in the city treasury by the city manager, shall be secured in such manner as may be directed by such city clerk, and shall be disbursed by such clerk to the persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of the court. 
(f)  The city may enforce the collection of any amount due on such lien for removal of abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or cutting of nuisance vegetation in the following manner: 
(1)  The owner or parties at interest, shall be allowed to satisfy the amount due on such lien by paying to the city within thirty (30) days after the perfection of such lien, a sum of money equal to twenty-five (25) percent of the total amount due and by further paying to the city the remaining balance due on such lien, together with interest at the legal rate, in three (3) annual payments, each of which shall become due and payable on the anniversary date of the initial payment made as described in this subsection. 
(2)  Should the property upon which such lien is perfected be sold, transferred, or conveyed by the owner or parties at interest at any time prior to the termination of the three-year period, then the entire balance due on such lien shall be due and payable to the city. 
(3)  Should the amount due on such lien, or any portion thereof, be unpaid after the passage of the three-year period, or upon the occurrence of the contingency provided for in subsection (2), the city may enforce the collection of any amount due on such lien for removal of the motor vehicles or other material or cutting of the nuisance vegetation in the same manner as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358, as amended, and other applicable state statutes. This procedure shall be subject to the right of redemption by any person having any right, title, or interest in or lien upon said property, all as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-4-40 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Sec. 12-23. - Powers of city manager in regard to abandoned/junk motor vehicles, or nuisance or junk material or cutting of nuisance vegetation. 
The following powers are given the city manager to carry out the duties to correct unsanitary conditions: 
(a)  To investigate the conditions in the city in order to determine which conditions relating the abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation are unsanitary, unsafe or detrimental to the community; 
(b)  To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; 
(c)  To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(d)  To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article; and 
(e)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under this article to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
Sec. 12-24. - Service of complaints, citations or orders upon parties in interest and owners of abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation. 
(a)  Complaints, citations or orders issued by the city manager or public official pursuant to this article shall, in all cases, be served upon each person in possession of such property, each owner, and each party in interest. The return of service signed by the city manager or public official or any affidavit of service executed by any citizen of this state, reciting that a copy of such complaint or order was served upon each person in possession of such property, each owner, and each party in interest personally or by leaving such copy at the place of his residence, shall be sufficient evidence as to the service of such person in possession, owner and party in interest. 
(b)  If any of the owners and parties in interest shall reside out of the city, service shall be perfected by causing a copy of such complaint or order to be served upon such party by the sheriff or any lawful deputy of the county of the residence of such party or parties, or such service may be made by any citizen or by registered or certified mail, return receipt provided. The return of such sheriff or lawful deputy or the affidavit of such citizen that such party or parties were served either personally or by leaving a copy of the complaint or order at the residence, shall be conclusive as to such service. 
(c)  Nonresidents of this state shall be served by posting a copy of such complaint or order in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order. Where the address of such nonresidents is known, a copy of such complaint or order shall be mailed to them by registered or certified mail, return receipt provided. 
(d)  If either the owner or any party in interest is a minor or an insane person or person laboring under disabilities, the guardians or other personal representative of such person shall be served and if such guardian or personal representative resides outside the city or is a nonresident, he shall be served as provided for in paragraph (b) or (c) in such cases. If such minor or insane person or person laboring [under] disabilities has no guardian or personal representative or if such minor or insane person lives outside the city or is a nonresident, service shall be perfected by serving such minor or insane person personally or by leaving a copy at the place of his residence, which shall be sufficient evidence as to the service of such person. In the case of other persons who live outside of the city or are nonresidents, service shall be perfected by serving the judge of the probate court of the county wherein such property is located who shall stand in the place of and protect the rights of such minor or insane person or appoint a guardian ad litem for such person. 
(e)  If the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest is unknown and such whereabouts cannot be ascertained by the city manager in the exercise of reasonable diligence and the city manager shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the service of such complaint or order upon such person shall be made in the same manner as provided in paragraph (c) or service may be perfected upon any person, firm or corporation holding itself out as an agent for the property involved. 
(f)  A copy of such complaint or order shall also be filed in the proper office or offices for the filing of lis pendens notice in the county in which the dwelling, building or structure is located and such filing of the complaint or order shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. Any such complaint or order an appropriate lis pendens notice may contain a statement to the effect that a lien may arise against the described property and that an itemized statement of such lien is maintained on a lien docket maintained by the clerk of the city. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Sec. 12-25. - Application to private property. 
All provisions of this article including method and procedure shall apply to private property of every type and nature where an accumulation of trash, junk, filth, and other unsanitary or unsafe conditions or the existence of nuisance vegetation shall create a public health hazard or a general nuisance to those persons residing in the vicinity. 
Sec. 12-26. - Removal of junk or abandoned vehicles upon public property. 
(a)  Any law enforcement officer of the city who finds a motor vehicle that has been left unattended on a public street or public property for a period of five (5) days shall be authorized to cause such motor vehicle to be removed to a garage or other place of safety, if the law enforcement officer reasonably believes that the person who left such motor vehicle unattended does not intend to return and remove the vehicle. 
(b)  Any law enforcement officer of the city who finds a motor vehicle that has been abandoned or left unattended on a public street of the city shall be authorized to cause such motor vehicle to be removed immediately to a garage or other place of safety when such motor vehicle poses a threat to public health or safety or to mitigate traffic congestion. 
(c)  Any law enforcement officer of the city who causes such motor vehicle to be removed to a garage or other place of safety shall be liable for gross negligence only. 
(d)  Any law enforcement office of the city causing a motor vehicle to be removed shall attempt to determine within seventy-two (72) hours of the time of removal the name of the owner of the vehicle through inquiry to the department of motor vehicles if necessary. The name and address obtained of the last registered owner shall be made available to the person removing the vehicle and the name of such lienholder as may be listed as holding a security interest in the vehicle within three (3) calendar days of removal of the vehicle. If this information is not available, the law enforcement officer shall within three (3) calendar days notify the person removing or storing such vehicle of such fact. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Sec. 12-27. - Removal of junk, appliances, and other personal property abandoned upon public property, penalty for permitting or falling to remove such property. 
No person or entity shall place or permit to remain any junk, litter, abandoned appliances, white goods or other personal property upon public property without the permission of the City of Cairo. Any law enforcement officer or employee of the city is hereby authorized to remove junk, litter, abandoned appliances, white goods, or personal property of any type located wholly or partially upon public property including the right-of-way of city streets as set forth herein. The city shall attempt to ascertain the owner of the junk, litter, abandoned appliances, white goods, or personal property that is found upon public property and commence with the immediate removal, or as scheduling permits, of the junk, litter, abandoned appliances, white goods, or personal property. The owner shall be required to pay to the city a charge for pickup according to a schedule adopted by mayor and council. 
If the owner cannot be determined following investigation, the city shall commence with the immediate removal, or as scheduling permits, of the junk, litter, abandoned appliances, white goods, or other personal property. Following removal, the city shall submit a notice of assessment to the person or entity that is reasonably believed to be the owner of the abandoned or junk property. The assessment will be in accordance with the established fee schedule shown above. Notice of assessment shall provide that the person receiving the notice shall have ten (10) days to controvert the assessment by submitting in writing to the city manager or his designee, the intent to controvert the assessment with the basis of the alleged property owner's denial of liability. Following the passage of ten (10) days from the mailing of the notice of assessment, an uncontroverted assessment shall be deemed valid. 
If controverted, the matter shall be heard by the city manager or his designee. A decision shall be made and communicated to the person controverting the assessment within ten (10) days. That decision may be appealed to the municipal court of the City of Cairo. Failure of the alleged owner of the abandoned property to controvert or pay the costs incurred shall permit the city of initiate legal action to collect the alleged sum owing through legal action as permitted by the laws of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Sec. 12-28. - Procedure relating to the citation of those who permit the existence of unsanitary and unsightly conditions on private property. 
(a)  At such time as the city manager or public official shall determine that there exists abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation on any property within the city, or whenever it appears to the city manager or public official that abandoned/junk motor vehicles, nuisance or junk material or nuisance vegetation exist within the city, the city manager or public official may issue a citation to the offending party, said party to be determined from the property records of the City of Cairo. Such option to issue a citation shall be in addition to that procedure set forth within sections 12-22 to 12-27 to remove unsanitary and unsightly conditions. 
(b)  Such citation may, at the option of the issuing party, be in the form of a warning that shall request that the specified unsightly and/or unsanitary condition be corrected within fifteen (15) days. At the option of the city manager or public official, but in no event sooner than fifteen (15) days if a warning has been issued regarding the condition and no action taken by the owner, the citation shall specify that the owner is in violation of this article setting forth the condition that violates this article, set forth the proposed bond/fine for the offense as established by the municipal court and the owner shall be required to appear in municipal court at the date and time designated by the public official. If the citation is controverted by the property owner, the public official shall present the evidence of the violation to the court. The municipal court shall have authority by court rule to permit forfeiture of the bond/fine on the first citation issued for the condition. 
(c)  If the offending party is found guilty of violation of this article, the judge of municipal court of the City of Cairo shall punish the offender as set forth in section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances or establish terms and conditions regarding correction of the unsafe, unsightly or unsanitary condition that are appropriate. 
(d)  The form of citation shall be approved by the city manager and judge of municipal court of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-28-07) 
Secs. 12-29—12-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 446, § 1, adopted June 12, 1995, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as set out in §§ 12-60—12-65. Prior to amendment, such article pertained to the same subject matter and was derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 16-23, 16-29—16-33, 16-36; and Ord. No. 229, adopted Dec. 13, 1976. 

Sec. 12-60. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings indicated: 
Nuisance: A condition dangerous to human life or detrimental to health that arises because a building, structure, or premises is not sufficiently ventilated, sewered, drained, cleaned or lighted so that in reference to its intended or actual use, the air, food, drink or water supply is unwholesome. 
Prohibited discharge: Discharge or spillage of sewage permitting seepage or discharge of effluent upon the ground surface, to a water course, drainage ditch, open trench, canal, storm drain or storm sewer, water well, abandoned well, lake, stream, river, estuary, ground water or other body of water. 
Septic tank: An approved watertight tank designed or used to receive sewage from a building or residential, commercial or industrial site and from which the effluent does not come to the surface of the ground but which is treated or processed before discharging the effluent to an absorption field or other management system. 
Sewage: Any liquid waste including human excreta, liquid household waste from residences, or from commercial and industrial establishments. 
(Ord. No. 446, § 1, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 12-61. - Sanitary method required. 
(a)  Every residence and building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregate, shall have a sanitary method of sewage disposal connected to the city sanitary sewer system, where a sewer connection is available. If a sanitary sewer connection is not available, a septic tank shall be provided of a type approved by the state department of public health. 
(b)  No person shall dispose of any sewage within the city except through a drainage pipe connected with a city sanitary sewer system if such connection is available or in any case that a sewer connection is not available then a septic tank of a type approved by the state department of health. 
(c)  No person or entity shall cause or permit a prohibited discharge or nuisance to exist as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 446, § 1, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 12-62. - Sanitary facilities on leased premises. 
No person owning or leasing any premises in the city shall permit a prohibited discharge or permit disposal of sewage on property leased or rented by such person or such persons' agent except in a sanitary manner through a system connected with the city sanitary sewer system where sewage connection is available, or where sewage connection is not available in a septic tank of a type approved by the state department of health. 
(Ord. No. 446, § 1, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 12-63. - Construction of septic tank. 
No septic tank other than a type approved by the state department of public health shall be constructed or maintained within the city. 
(Ord. No. 446, § 1, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 12-64. - Privy. 
No person shall construct or maintain a privy or dry closet within the city except for temporary use on a construction site. 
(Ord. No. 446, § 1, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 12-65. - Connection to sanitary sewer system. 
Every residence and other building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregate, shall have a sanitary water closet and all sewage resulting from the use of the residence or building shall be disposed of through the city sanitary sewer within twelve (12) months from the date that a sewer connection is available. The failure or refusal of any owner of such residence or building to connect to the sanitary sewer system within twelve (12) months from the date such connection is available shall be a violation of this Code and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. Each thirty-day period such sewer connection is not connected shall be a new offense. 
(Ord. No. 446, § 1, 6-12-95) 
Secs. 12-66—12-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ALARM SYSTEMS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 513, adopted 12-14-98, amended art. IV in its entirety to read as set out in §§ 12-70—12-85. Prior to such amendment, art. IV, §§ 12-70—12-74, pertained to the same subject matter and was derived from Ord. No. 370, § 1, adopted Apr. 9. 1990. 

Sec. 12-70. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. 
Alarm agent means any person employed by an alarm business whose duties include the altering, installing, maintaining, moving, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing, responding to or causing others to respond to an alarm device. 
Alarm business means any business operated by a person for a profit which engages in the activity of altering, installing, leasing, maintaining, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing or responding to a burglar or robbery alarm system or which causes any of these activities to take place. 
Alarm system means any assembly of equipment and devices designed to signal the presence of a potential hazard relayed by an alarm answering service or any other audible or silent alarm device to which the police are expected to respond. In this article, the term "alarm system" shall include the terms "automatic robbery alarm systems," "burglar alarm systems," "robbery alarm systems," "manual robbery alarm systems" and "intrusion alarms" as those terms are hereinafter defined. Fire alarm systems and alarm systems which monitor temperature, humidity or any other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted burglary or robbery at a premises are specifically excluded from the provisions of this article. 
Alarm user means any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the city, except for alarm systems on motor vehicles or proprietary systems. If, however, an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected with an alarm system at a premises (other than a proprietary system), the person using such system is an alarm user. Also excluded from this definition and from the coverage of this article are persons who use alarm systems to alert or signal persons within the premises in which the alarm system is located, of an attempted burglary, unauthorized intrusion or robbery attempt. If such a system, however, employs an audible signal emitting sounds or a flashing light or beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such system shall be within the definition of "alarm system" and shall be subject to this article. 
Automatic dialing system means an alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by electronic or optical impulse, radio waves or by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice, text or data message to 911 indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
Burglary alarm system means an alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into an area protected by the system. 
Chief of police shall mean the City of Cairo Chief of Police or his/her designee. 
City means the City of Cairo. 
Commercial alarm means an alarm installed on premises which is primarily used for one or more of the following: 
(a)  Business providing sales, service or both; 
(b)  Public agency or nonprofit entity or organization providing service to the general public or a significant segment thereof. 
Commercial alarm does not include any alarm installed on premises primarily used for residential purposes. 
Emergency alarm system means any devise which is designed to alert, either directly or indirectly, personnel of the police department to any emergency situation. 
False alarm means a non-emergency activation of an alarm system due to mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or maintenance or the negligence of the owner, lessee or his/her employees or agents which results in a response by the city police department. 
False alarm does not include alarm activations caused by tornadoes, earthquakes or other violent, uncontrollable, acts of nature. 
Interconnect means to connect an alarm system to a voice, text or data line, either directly or through any device that utilizes hard wire or radio transmissions, for the purpose of transmitting emergency message upon the activation of the alarm system. Interconnect includes connection to radio transmitters and other text and data carrying or transmission devices. 
Intrusion alarm system means an alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into the area protected by the system. 
Local alarm system means an audible or visual alarm system that can be heard or seen from the exterior of a structure within which the system is installed. 
Manual robbery alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the direct action of the person attacked or by an observer of the attack. 
One-year period means the period of time commencing upon the occurrence of an initial false alarm, and terminating one (1) year following the initial false alarm. 
Police chief means the chief of police of the Cairo Police Department or his/her designated representative. 
Police or police department means the City of Cairo Police Department. 
Premises means any privately owned real property or structures located within the city (excluding land or structures owned, occupied by, rented or leased to the federal, state, or local government entities). 
Proprietor alarm means an alarm which is not serviced by an alarm business. 
Proprietary system means an alarm system sounding and/or recording alarm and supervisory signals at a control center located within the protected premises, and under the supervision of the proprietor of the protected premises. If a proprietary system includes a signal line connected directly or by means of an automatic dialing device to a police communications center, a central station, modified central station or answering service, it thereby becomes an "alarm system" as defined herein. 
Remote signaling system means an alarm signaling system which, when activated by an alarm device, transmits a signal from an alarm signaling device to a central location, other than the communications center, where appropriate action is taken to investigate and respond to the signal. 
Responsible party means any person, or their agent, representative or designee who owns, leases, or is lawfully in charge of the premises on which an alarm system is installed or maintained, or who owns, leases, or uses an alarm system on premises located within the city. 
Revocation of permit means an order by the chief of police revoking an alarm system permit and forbidding use of an alarm system until proof of correction is provided following two (2) or more suspensions of an alarm permit over a twelve-month period. 
Robbery alarm system means an alarm system signaling a robbery, attempted robbery, or the commission of a crime involving potential death or serious injury at a specific particular location. 
Service charge means the amount prescribed by the mayor and council which represents the costs incurred by the city in providing extraordinary alarm system service as described in section 12-72. 
Shall is always mandatory and not directory. 
Suspension of permit means: 
(a)  An action taken by the chief of police to suspend an alarm system permit following demand for proof of correction of the alarm system; or 
(b)  An alarm management procedure to assure correction of the cause(s) of false alarms from a permitted alarm system. 
Subscriber means a person who buys and/or leases or otherwise obtains an alarm signaling system and thereafter contracts with or hires an alarm business to monitor and/or service the alarm device. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-71. - Alarm business and agent responsibilities. 
(a)  No person shall maintain an alarm business in the city without having first obtained a business license from the city and satisfying all alarm business registration requirements of the State of Georgia and registration of the name shown on the state issued identification card with the chief of police. Any person acting as an alarm agent or responding alarm agent shall carry the registration card issued by the State of Georgia while engaged in alarm agent activities and shall display such registration card to a representative of the police department upon request. 
(b)  Any person or business who leases, maintains, sells, or installs any alarm system or who causes such systems to be leased, maintained, sold or installed shall inform any and all responsible persons about: the operational, remedy and penalty provisions contained within this article; the false alarm suspension provisions contained within this article. 
(1)  Automatic dial telephone devices are prohibited and the police department will not respond to signals from such devices. 
(2)  The chief of police may suspend a permittee whose alarm system has experienced three (3) false alarms in a ninety-day period or more than six (6) false alarm response within a twelve-month period which did not require police services for any purpose other than the deactivation of the alarm. 
(3)  No person shall operate or use an alarm system which causes a request for service to be placed with the police department prior to the verification of the need for such service by either physical inspection of the scene of activation, remote electronic inspection of the scene, or an attempt to verify the need for service by telephonic means. 
(4)  The operational requirements, the remedies and penalty provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-72. - Alarm system permit; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall possess or use an alarm system without first applying for and receiving an alarm permit as required by this article. 
(b)  In the event a residential alarm user is assessed a civil penalty as provided in section 12-83 for failure to have a permit as required by this article, the permit fee shall be satisfied from the civil penalty amount paid by the residential alarm user. The permit for the alarm shall be issued to the residential alarm user upon the alarm user's submission of a completed application permit form. 
(c)  No alarm permit shall be required for any of the following: 
(1)  Persons engaged solely in the manufacture repair or sale of alarm systems or components from a fixed location who do not personally or through an agent install, maintain, service, inspect or plan the alarm system for any location. 
(2)  Alarm systems which do not directly alert law enforcement agencies or others outside the protected buildings, structure or facility, but are designed solely to alert security personnel or others directly connected with or employed by the owner or operator of the protected building, structure or facility. 
(3)  Municipal, county, state or federal government agencies. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-73. - Obtaining and filing of permits; required information. 
(a)  Permits required by this article shall be obtained from and filed with the city hall which shall prescribe the permit form. Permits for alarm systems installed by an alarm company may be issued by an agent of the company using the prescribed form and forwarding a copy to the city hall with payment of required fees. 
(b)  The permit must contain the names, addresses, and telephone numbers of three (3) persons who will render service and repairs to a malfunctioning alarm system and authorize access to the interior and exterior of the premises for a security check at any time of the day or night. 
(c)  Alarm companies, when servicing or repairing pre-existing alarms which have not been issued a permit, shall issue the responsible party an alarm permit as provided for in subsection (a), or provide the responsible party with an application form for an alarm permit and advise the responsible party of the requirements of this ordinance as per section 12-72. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-74. - Alarm permit duration and transfer. 
An alarm permit may be issued at any time, but all alarm permits expire on the last day of the 24th month following issuance of the permit. Alarm permits shall not be transferable from one person to another, from one location to another, and such permits may not be transferred with the land or structure. Any such transfer shall be void. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-75. - Fees. 
The mayor and council establish the following fee schedule related to this article: 
(a)  Application fee for all permits required by this article is twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(b)  Service fee responses to false alarms pursuant to section 12-71 is twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(c)  Inspection fee of alarm systems following suspension or revocation of a permit is twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-76. - Permit to be kept on alarm system premises; posting of permit. 
(a)  The permits issued pursuant to this article shall be kept on the premises where the alarm system is located. The police department may issue an appropriate identification tag and establish requirements for its posting. 
(b)  No person shall use an alarm system without posting the alarm system permit number at the front entrance of the premises served by the alarm system. 
Street address numbers shall be clearly visible and readable from the exterior of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-77. - Alarm requirements. 
(a)  No audible alarm shall be installed, maintained or activated which emits the sound of a siren similar to those utilized on emergency vehicles or for air raid, disaster or other emergency warnings. 
(b)  Audible alarm systems which can be heard outside the building, structure or facility of the alarm user shall be equipped with a sound emission cutoff feature, which will stop the emission of sound fifteen (15) minutes or less after the alarm is activated. Alarm systems without properly functioning sound emission cutoff features will be designated as a nuisance and be subject to abatement by the police department. 
(c)  The responsible party shall post a notice containing the name and telephone number of all persons to be notified to render repairs or services during any time that the audible alarm sounds. 
(d)  Such notice shall be posted near the alarm in such a position as to be easily readable in size, form and style from the ground level adjacent to the building. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-78. - Duty to deactivate alarm after notice; duty to respond and provide police access to premises; penalty for failure to respond. 
(a)  The responsible party shall deactivate any alarm within thirty (30) minutes after police department notification to the responsible party that such alarm is activated and is sounding. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the responsible party to cause, permit, suffer or allow such system to sound for a period in excess of thirty (30) minutes after notification or efforts of notification have been made. 
(c)  The responsible party shall proceed to the premises within thirty (30) minutes after notice or efforts of notification and render any assistance necessary service, including, but is not limited to, providing access to the property for a search by the police department. Failure of the responsible party to respond to the premises may result in a citation. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-79. - Suspension and revocation of permit; grounds. 
(a)  The chief of police may suspend any permittee whose alarm system has experienced three (3) false alarms in a ninety-day period or six (6) false alarms within a twelve-month period. 
(b)  Failure of the police department to locate any evidence of intrusion or other need or cause for activating an alarm system shall result in the presumption of a false alarm. If within ten (10) days of notification the chief of police receives from the permittee satisfactory evidence that the alarm was valid because it was excusable or was an alarm caused by an unauthorized entry, attempted unauthorized entry, or other unlawful activity on the alarm site, the permittee's record will be amended to indicate a valid or excusable alarm. 
(c)  The chief of police shall notify the permittee in writing that the alarm system permit has been suspended. The permittee may submit the proper fees for a reissued permit and satisfactory written evidence indicating that the cause of the false alarm has been determined and corrected. 
(d)  More than two (2) suspensions in any year shall be the basis for revocation of the permit and police department non response to the alarm. Petition may be made to reinstate the alarm permit and response to alarms upon compliance with the requirements in the police chief's letter of alarm permit revocation. 
(e)  Any alarm user whose alarm permit has been suspended or revoked shall immediately discontinue use of their alarm system until such time as the suspension is rescinded or the alarm permit is reissued. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly activate an alarm system after the permit has been suspended or revoked. Unlawful activation of an alarm system will result in the issuance of a citation. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-80. - Suspension or revocation appeals. 
The decision of the chief of police to suspend or revoke a permit may be appealed to the chief of police, in writing, within ten (10) days of written notice. A hearing will then be scheduled to be held before a hearing officer appointed by the city manager concerning the issues raised in the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-81. - Inspection of alarm devices and businesses. 
(a)  For the purposes of enforcing this article, the police chief shall have the authority at reasonable times and upon reasonable oral notice, to enter any commercial premises in the city in or upon which alarm systems or alarm businesses subject to this article are located, to inspect the installation and/or operation of such alarm systems or alarm businesses. If such entry is refused, the police chief shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(b)  For the purposes of enforcing this article, the police chief shall have authority to inspect residential dwellings which have alarm systems after he has given written notice to the owner of such residence that he wishes to inspect the alarm system. If such entry is refused, the police chief shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. The written notice shall be given at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the inspection. 
(c)  If such inspection reveals any violation of the provisions of this article, a written report detailing such violation shall be promptly sent to the owner, lessee or other person responsible for the violation. Such report shall require the correction within thirty (30) days of the mailing of the notice of violation. The alarm user or alarm business shall be granted a reasonable extension of time to correct such violation upon good cause shown. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and willfully reveal any business information obtained during said inspection other than for official police business or for the administration of this article and law enforcement purposes. 
(e)  The amount of the service charge shall be set by the mayor and council in the published fee schedule based upon the city cost of the service provided. 
(Ord. No. 513, 12-14-98) 
Sec. 12-82. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person shall operate or use a robbery alarm system for any other purpose other than reporting robberies or other crimes involving potential serious bodily injury or death. 
(b)  No person shall operate or use a burglary alarm system for any purpose other than detecting and reporting an unauthorized entry or an attempted unauthorized entry upon the premises protected by such system. 
(c)  No person shall operate or use an alarm system that causes more than two (2) requests for services in any continuous twelve-month period without prior verification of the need for the service. "Verification of need for the service" means an effort to ascertain the existence of an unauthorized entry justifying a police service response. Verification may be accomplished by physical inspection of the alarm location, remote electronic inspection, or telephonic verification.
