(a)  A person commits the crime of disorderly conduct, if, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, such person shall: 
(1)  Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of safety of his life, limb or health; or 
(2)  Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; or 
(3)  Endanger the lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats and abusive conduct; or 
(4)  Cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another; or 
(5)  Assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl; or 
(6)  Jostle or roughly crowd or push any person in any public place; or 
(7)  Collect in bodies or crowds for unlawful purposes as defined by the ordinances of the city; or 
(8)  Assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose or with the intent to engage in unlawful gaming; or 
(9)  Frequent any public place with intent to take money from other persons by illegal and fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; or 
(10)  Assemble for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, devise or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place from any person in the city or who shall aid or abet therein; or 
(11)  Accost or attempt to force his company upon any person, male or female, or attempt to pickup any person, male or female; or 
(12)  Utter or use in the presence of another any bawdy, lewd, abusive or obscene language or make an obscene gesture; or 
(13)  Frequent any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated; or 
(14)  Use "fighting words" directed towards any person or becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; or 
(15)  Assemble or congregate for the purpose of trouncing on or accosting another; or 
(16)  By act of violence interfere with the pursuit of the lawful occupation of another; or 
(17)  Congregate with another or others on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and/or refuses to clear the public way when ordered by the city police or other lawful authority; or 
(18)  Congregate with another or other persons in a public place and refuse to comply with the lawful order of the police to disburse; or 
(19)  Operate a motor vehicle upon a parking area, public or private, vehicle access, or pedestrian walkway of any parking area and by sudden starting, stopping, or turning so as to endanger the person or property of another; or 
(20)  Operate a motor vehicle upon any parking area, public or private, vehicle access or pedestrian walkway of any parking facility at a speed great enough to endanger the person or property of another; or 
(21)  Operate a motor vehicle upon any pedestrian walkway or sidewalk, public or private in any manner; or 
(22)  Consume alcoholic beverages or possess or have under his control an open container of any alcoholic beverage in any public area including property of the city, state, or county by and through its elected or appointed political agencies or boards; or 
(23)  Operate a motor vehicle and have therein under his possession and/or control or the possession and/or control of any person within the automobile an open container of any type containing an alcoholic beverage; or 
(24)  Be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant or within a place of business patronized by the public, such condition made manifest by boisterousness, indecent condition or act or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language; or 
(25)  Aid, abet or encourage a minor to do any act which constitutes disorderly conduct or a breach of the peace. 
(b)  A person commits the offense of public indecency when he or she performs any of the following acts in a place where a person should reasonably expect to be in view of the public: 
(1)  An actual or simulated act of sexual intercourse or masturbation; 
(2)  A lewd exposure of the sexual organs; 
(3)  A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; 
(4)  A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person; or 
(5)  Urination or defecation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in public wearing pants, shorts, or skirts more than three (3) inches below the top of the hips (crest of the ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "undergarments" shall include any article of clothing worn under the outer garments and next to the skin. Any person(s) violating this subsection may be warned by the law enforcement officer to pull up their pants, shorts, or skirts, and if they comply, said warning shall be the penalty for violation of this subsection. Failure by said person(s) to comply with said warning shall result in a charge of "disorderly conduct;" and a citation shall be issued to the offender, and the person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) on the first offense and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each subsequent offense. Any violation for this offense shall not, in and of itself, be grounds for an arrest or for search of the person cited. 
(Code 1965, § 20-4; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 7-23-90; Ord. No. 743, 11-12-12) 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order, OCGA § 16-11-30 et seq. 
Sec. 15-4. - Defacing city hall. 
No person shall spit upon, or make pencil marks or other marks upon the floors, walls, staircases or other parts of the city hall or deface or damage in any other manner any part of such building. 
(Code 1965, § 20-2) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, OCGA § 16-7-21. 
Sec. 15-5. - Weapons; discharging. 
(A)  No person shall negligently or purposely discharge any firearm, BB gun or slingshot within the city, except: 
(1)  In necessary self defense. 
(2)  A law enforcement officer in necessary performance of official duty. 
(3)  For the purpose of target shooting or practice on a range operated by qualified personnel. "Qualified personnel" shall consist of a certified firearms safety instructor, rifle or pistol marksmanship instructor certified by the national rifle association, or a person designated by a rifle or pistol club, public or private school or military agency. 
(4)  Target shooting on private premises with air or carbon dioxide-operated BB or with a pellet gun or slingshot, providing: 
(a)  The target area is enclosed in such manner and with such materials that will stop the projectiles. 
(b)  Such target shooting is supervised by an adult at all times. 
(c)  Any safety precautions recommended by the police chief are complied with. 
(5)  Where a permit has been issued by the police chief. 
(B)  "Firearms," as used in this section, shall mean any device that expels a projectile by means of expending gases. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-5, 20-6) 
State Law reference— Discharge of firearms, OCGA § 16-11-103 et seq. 
Sec. 15-6. - Gambling. 
No two (2) or more persons shall assemble at any place within the city for the purpose of playing and betting for money or other thing of value on any game played with cards, dice or balls, or for the purpose of playing and betting for money or other thing of value on any game whatever. 
(Code 1965, § 20-7) 
State Law reference— Gambling, OCGA § 16-12-20 et seq. 
Sec. 15-7. - Lewd houses. 
(a)  No person shall keep or maintain a lewd or disreputable house for the purpose of engaging in lewd or disreputable acts. 
(b)  No person shall lodge or live in any such house. 
(c)  In any prosecution for violation of this section, it shall be considered sufficient evidence that such place is a rendezvous for persons, either male or female, of notoriously bad, disreputable or lewd habits. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-8, 20-9) 
State Law reference— Keeping place of prostitution, OCGA § 16-6-10; disorderly house, § 16-11-44. 
Sec. 15-8. - Congregating on sidewalks. 
No two (2) or more persons shall congregate on the sidewalks of the city so as to obstruct such sidewalks. 
(Code 1965, § 28-3) 
Sec. 15-9. - Loitering. 
(a)  No boy or girl under the age of sixteen (16) years shall loiter or remain upon the streets of the city after 11:00 p.m. without good cause or necessity. 
(b)  No person shall be in or remain in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
Such circumstances that may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that a person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impractical, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern that would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(Code 1965, § 20-10; Ord. No. 329, § 1, 8-8-88) 
Cross reference— Loitering in city parks and recreation areas, § 24-1. 
State Law reference— Loitering, OCGA § 16-11-36. 
Sec. 15-10. - Political activities on public streets and ways. 
No person shall stand on any public street or way in the city for the purpose of distributing political campaign literature, campaign cards, or soliciting votes. Such act shall be an offense and upon conviction the defendant shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 28-6; Ord. No. 248, 8-25-80) 
Sec. 15-11. - Parades—Definitions. 
As used in section 15-12, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Assemble: The action of any group of persons who congregate on any public street, alley or sidewalk in the city for the purpose of displaying, advertising, promoting, exhibiting, advocating or otherwise attracting public attention to or for any cause or thing. 
Parade: The action of any group of persons marching or promenading on and along any public street, alley or sidewalk in the city for the purpose of displaying, advertising, promoting, exhibiting, advocating or otherwise attracting public attention to or for any cause or thing. 
(Code 1965, § 20-14) 
Sec. 15-12. - Same—Permit required; participation in unlawful parade. 
(a)  No two (2) or more persons shall parade or assemble or congregate on any public street, alley or sidewalk in the city for a purpose set out in section 15-11 unless the governing body shall have previously approved and authorized such parade or assembly. 
(b)  Any person participating in or attending any parade or assembly which has not been so authorized and approved shall be considered a part of the group constituting such parade or assembly, and shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 20-15) 
State Law reference— Unlawful assembly, OCGA § 16-11-33; refusal to disperse, § 16-10-30. 
Sec. 15-13. - Same—Permit application. 
Any two (2) or more persons proposing to parade or assemble on any of the public streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city for any of the purposes defined in section 15-11 shall file an application with the governing body setting out the time, place and purpose of such parade or assembly. Any application for a permit hereunder must be presented and action taken thereon at the next regular meeting of the governing body. 
(Code 1965, § 20-16; Ord. No. 172, § 1, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 15-14. - Same—Wearing masks. 
(a)  No two (2) or more persons shall parade upon the streets or within the city wearing masks or any other disguise or device whereby the identity of such persons is obscured or hidden or the license plate of automobiles are covered. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to parades at Halloween, Christmas, and other like traditional celebrations wherein it is the custom to wear masks, provided permission to do so is first obtained from the governing body. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-12, 20-13) 
State Law reference— Wearing masks, OCGA § 16-11-38. 
Sec. 15-15. - Entering and disturbing premises. 
(a)  No person shall enter the premises of another for the purpose of creating or provoking a disturbance or breach of the peace. 
(b)  In the interpretation and enforcement of this section, when any person enters upon the premises of another for a certain purpose and the fulfillment of accomplishment of such purpose, or attempt thereof, gives rise to, causes or provokes a disturbance or breach of peace, it shall be presumed that the entering upon the premises was for the purpose of creating or provoking such disturbance or breach of the peace. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20-22, 20-23) 
Sec. 15-16. - Energy load management program; disconnecting radio switches. 
(a)  No person, including specifically the following: Owner, tenant, occupant, electrician, air conditioner mechanic or maintenance person or any officer, agent or employee of any of the above, shall disconnect the radio switch on the control thermostat circuit on air conditioners that has been installed by the city as a part of the load management program, except by written authorization of the city manager or the designated agent of the city manager. 
(b)  No person shall claim or receive a refund from the city paid as incentive for cooperation with the load management program after the radio switch on the control thermostat circuit on air conditioners has been disconnected. 
(c)  The disconnection of said radio switch by any person, as above defined or identified in subsection (a) is an offense and upon conviction the defendant shall be punished as provided in section 1-8, and each week that said switch is disconnected shall be a new offense. 
(d)  The claiming or receiving of the refund set forth in subsection (b) above by any person shall be an offense and upon conviction the defendant shall be punished as provided in section 1-8, and each such claim for a refund or receipt of said refund shall be a new offense. 
(Code 1965, § 20-25; Ord. No. 247, 7-28-80) 
Sec. 15-17. - Possession of marijuana. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess one ounce, or less, of marijuana within the corporate limits of the City of Cairo, Georgia. 
(a)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Cairo, Georgia. 
(b)  The jurisdiction of the municipal court of the City of Cairo shall be concurrent with the jurisdiction of any other court within the county having jurisdiction to try and dispose of such cases. 
(c)  Any fines and forfeitures arising from the prosecution of such cases shall be retained by the municipality and shall be paid into the treasury of such municipality. 
(d)  Any defendant charged with possession of an ounce or less of marijuana in a municipal court of the City of Cairo shall be entitled on request to have the case against him transferred to the court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county wherein the alleged offense occurred. 
(Ord. No. 284, § 1, 2-25-85) 
Sec. 15-18. - Theft by shoplifting. 
(a)  No person acting alone or in concert with another person, with the intent of appropriating merchandise to his own use without paying for same or to deprive the owner of possession thereof or of the value thereof, in whole or in part, [shall commit the offense of shoplifting] by doing any of the following: 
(1)  Concealing or taking possession of the goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment; 
(2)  Altering the price tag or other price marking on goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment; 
(3)  Transferring the goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment from one container to another; 
(4)  Interchanging the label or price tag from one item of merchandise with a label or price tag for another item of merchandise; or 
(5)  Wrongfully causing the amount paid to be less than the merchant's stated price for the merchandise. 
(b)  A person convicted of this offense shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Cairo, Georgia. 
(c)  The jurisdiction of the municipal court of the City of Cairo shall be concurrent with the jurisdiction of any other court within the county having jurisdiction to try and dispose of such cases. 
(d)  Any fines and forfeitures arising from the prosecution of such cases shall be retained by the municipality and shall be paid into the treasury of such municipality. 
(e)  Any defendant charged with the crime of theft by shoplifting in the municipal court of the City of Cairo shall be entitled on request to have the case against him transferred to the court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county wherein the alleged offense occurred. 
(Ord. No. 331, § 1, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 15-19. - Simple assault. 
(a)  No person shall commit the offense of simple assault which shall be defined as an attempt to commit a violent injury to the person of another or committing an act which places another in reasonable apprehension of immediately receiving a violent injury. 
(b)  A defendant charged with simple assault in the Municipal Court of the City of Cairo shall be entitled upon request to have the case against the defendant transferred to a court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county where the alleged offense occurred. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 1, 6-9-08) 
Sec. 15-20. - Simple battery. 
(a)  No person shall commit the offense of simple battery which shall be defined as: 
(1)  An intentional physical contact of an insulting and provoking nature to another person; 
(2)  Intentional physical harm to another; or 
(3)  Intentionally causing visible harm to another which may include, but is not limited to, substantially blackened eyes, swollen lips or other facial or body parts or substantial bruises to body parts. 
(b)  A defendant charged with simple battery in the Municipal Court of the City of Cairo shall be entitled upon request to have the case against the defendant transferred to a court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county where the alleged offense occurred. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 2, 6-9-08) 
Sec. 15-21. - Criminal trespass. 
(a)  No person shall commit the offense of criminal trespass. Criminal trespass shall be defined as: 
(1)  Intentionally damaging any property in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less of another without consent of that person or knowingly and maliciously interfering with the possession or use of the property of another person without the consent of that person; 
(2)  Knowingly and without authority entering upon the land or premises of another person or any part of a vehicle, watercraft or aircraft, of another person for an unlawful purpose; 
(3)  Entering upon the land or premises of another person or any part of any vehicle, watercraft or aircraft, after receiving prior to such entry, notice from the owner, rightful occupant or upon proper identification, an authorized representative of the owner, that such entry is forbidden; or 
(4)  Remaining upon the land or premises of another or within any vehicle, watercraft or aircraft, after receiving notice from the rightful owner, rightful occupant or upon proper identification, an authorized representative of the owner or rightful occupant, to depart. 
(b)  A defendant charged with criminal trespass in the Municipal Court of the City of Cairo shall be entitled upon request to have the case against the defendant transferred to a court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county where the alleged offense occurred. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 3, 6-9-08) 
Sec. 15-22. - Theft by taking. 
(a)  No person shall unlawfully take or be in unlawful possession thereof or unlawfully appropriate any property in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less of another with intention of depriving that person of the property, regardless of the manner in which the property is taken or appropriated. 
(b)  A defendant charged with theft by taking in the Municipal Court of the City of Cairo shall be entitled upon request to have the case against the defendant transferred to a court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county where the alleged offense occurred. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 4, 6-9-08) 
Chapter 16 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1—16-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RETIREMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-20. - Plan continued in effect. 
The retirement plan of the city, established by ordinance enacted on August 13, 1971, and thereafter amended, copies of which are on file in the city clerk's office, is hereby made a part hereof and is continued in full force and effect, as fully as if set out at length herein. 
Secs. 16-21—16-29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 16-30. - Declaration of policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest possible date under the agreement entered into by the state and the federal social security administrator, to the employees and officials thereof and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this division, the benefits of the system of old-age and survivors' insurance authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 134 of the 81st Congress, and as provided for in OCGA § 47-18-1 et seq. 
(Code 1965, § 24-11) 
Sec. 16-31. - Exclusions from coverage. 
There is hereby excluded from this division authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal law or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 24-12) 
Sec. 16-32. - Firefighters and police officers specifically included in benefits. 
Firefighters and police officers of the city are hereby specifically included as employees of the city and are entitled to all benefits of the system of old-age and survivors' insurance provided by this division regardless of exclusions provided. 
(Code 1965, § 24-13) 
Sec. 16-33. - Agreements with state agency. 
The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the employees' retirement system of the state to carry out the purposes of this division. 
(Code 1965, § 24-14) 
Sec. 16-34. - Withholdings from salaries and wages. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in this division are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal law or regulations, and shall be paid over to the employees' retirement system of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 24-15) 
Sec. 16-35. - Contributions by city. 
(a)  There shall be appropriated from the general funds of the city such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal law or regulations for employers' contributions, administrative expenses, and a guaranty fund to assure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in this division. 
(b)  Such funds shall be paid over to the employees' retirement system of the state in accordance with regulations established by such agency. 
(Code 1965, § 24-16) 
Sec. 16-36. - Records and reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal law or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 24-17) 
Secs. 16-37—16-44. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CODE OF ETHICS[1] 
All government, of right, originates with the people, is founded upon their will only, and is instituted solely for the good of the whole. Public officers are the trustees and servants of the people and are at all times amenable to them.  (Georgia Constitution, Article 1, Section 11, Paragraph 1) 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 724, adopted Nov. 8, 2010, repealed the former art. III, §§ 16-45—16-64, and enacted a new art. III as set out herein. The former art. III pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 

Sec. 16-45. - Purpose. 
The public trust requires public servants to fulfill their duties faithfully and honestly and to subordinate any personal interest which conflicts with the public interest. A public servant is a trustee of the people and should strive to further the general welfare and not use public office in order to improve his or her own private standing. The principle policies which form the foundation of this code of ethics are: 
(a)  The trust of citizens in their government is cultivated when individual public servants act with integrity and when the public is aware that its servants act with integrity. 
(b)  The constitutions, laws and regulations of the United States and State of Georgia and ordinances of the City of Cairo should be upheld as a de minimus standard of conduct. 
(c)  The most effective way to eradicate unethical practices is to consistently act with the highest moral principles and to consistently react appropriately to the ethical decisions of others. 
(d)  Elected officials should exercise sound judgment and apply ethical principles in making decisions that in any manner reflect upon their elected office. 
(e)  All citizens should be treated with courtesy, impartiality and equality. 
(f)  Those persons who fail to abide by the terms of this code of ethics should be disciplined. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-46. - Intent. 
It is the intent of this code of ethics that any city official shall not knowingly engage in any activity which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his or her official duties or which would tend to impair his or her judgment or actions in the performance of his or her official duties. Furthermore, city officials should avoid any action which might result in or create the appearance of the following: 
(a)  Using public office for private gain. 
(b)  Impeding city efficiency or economy. 
(c)  Affecting adversely the confidence of the public in the integrity of those who conduct the affairs and business of the City of Cairo. 
Not withstanding anything herein to the contrary, state law and the Charter of the city shall be controlling in the event of an actual conflict with the provisions of this code of ethics. This article shall be interpreted to supplement, and not replace, said provisions of state law and the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-47. - Definitions. 
(a)  Benefit shall mean: 
(1)  Anything, regardless of its monetary value, perceived or intended by either the one who offers it or the one to whom it is offered, to be sufficient in value to influence a city official in the performance or nonperformance of an official action; or 
(2)  Anything, regardless of its monetary value, which, under the circumstances, a reasonably prudent person would recognize as being likely to be intended to influence a city official in the performance or nonperformance of an official action. 
(b)  City official or official shall mean, unless otherwise expressly defined does not include city employees but does mean the mayor, members of the city council, municipal court judges (including substitute judges), city manager, city clerk, city attorney, and all other persons holding or elected to positions designated by the City Charter, as amended. The term "city official" also includes all individuals, including city employees, appointed by the mayor and/or city council as appropriate to city authorities, commissions, committees, boards, task forces, or other bodies which can or may vote or take formal action or make official recommendations to the mayor and/or city council. 
(c)  Decision shall mean any ordinance, resolution, contract, franchise, formal action or other matter voted on by the city council or other city board or commission, as well as the discussions or deliberations of the council, board, or commission which can or may lead to a vote or formal action by that body. 
(d)  Employee shall mean any person who is employed in a position covered by the position classification plan of the City of Cairo; any person who is employed part-time by any operating department of the City of Cairo; and any person who is employed through a contractual agreement with the City of Cairo. 
(e)  Government or city shall mean the City of Cairo, Georgia. 
(f)  Immediate family shall mean spouse, child, parent, grandparent or sibling of any city official by blood, adoption or marriage. 
(g)  Interest shall mean any direct or indirect financial gain accruing to a city official as a result of a contract or transaction that is, or may be, the subject of an official act or action by, or with, the city. Interest shall not mean any direct or indirect financial gain which is remote or insignificant. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-48. - Acceptance of gifts. 
A city official shall not solicit or accept, directly or indirectly, any benefit, special privilege, or exemption from any person, corporation or group which has, or is seeking to obtain, contractual or other business or financial relationships with the City of Cairo. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-49. - Financial interests. 
(a)  A city official may not: 
(1)  Have a direct or indirect financial interest that conflicts with his or her responsibilities and duties as a trustee of the public good. 
(2)  Either directly or indirectly engage in financial transactions as a result of, or primarily relying upon, information obtained in the course of his or her office or received due to his or her position. 
(b)  A city official shall be deemed to have a financial interest in transactions involving the following: 
(1)  Any person in the member's immediate family. 
(2)  Any person with whom a contractual relationship exists whereby the member may receive any payment or other benefits. 
(3)  Any business in which the city official is director, officer, employee, agent, or shareholder. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-50. - Use of public property. 
A city official shall not use City of Cairo property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor shall he or she direct employees to use such property for other than official purposes. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-51. - Use of confidential information. 
A city official shall not directly make use of, or permit others to make use of, for the purpose of furthering a private interest, city information not made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-52. - Coercion. 
(a)  A city official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any benefits to him or her or to persons within his or her family, or for those with whom the city official has business or financial ties. 
(b)  A city official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, a city employee, an appointed official of the city or a contract employee to provide any benefit to him or her or to persons within his or her immediate family. 
(c)  A city official shall not use his or her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, a municipal court judge in the outcome of matters before the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-53. - Purchases. 
A city official shall not order any goods or services for the City of Cairo or on behalf of the City of Cairo without prior authorization from the mayor and council or its designee. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-54. - City employees. 
A city official shall not use a city employee for personal or private business during regular business hours or during the employee's scheduled shift. A city official shall pay just compensation and shall not receive or expect a discount or special rate. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-55. - Travel expenses. 
A city official shall not draw per diem or expense money from the City of Cairo to attend a seminar, convention, conference or similar meeting and then fail to attend the seminar, conference, convention or similar meeting. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-56. - Commitments. 
A city official shall not act or create the appearance of acting on behalf of a member of council or other city official by promising to authorize or prevent any future official action of any nature, without prior authorization from the mayor and council or its designee. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-57. - Candidates. 
No person who has qualified seeking to become an elected official shall make a false or materially misleading statement or in any manner commit fraud or conceal wrong doing or withhold information regarding wrong doing in relation to any city or public business. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-58. - Disclosure. 
A city official shall disclose the nature of any interest or benefit he or she has at the time such matter is presented to the mayor and council for discussion and/or action. Such disclosure shall be recorded into the minutes of the meeting and become part of the public record. Following any disclosure made pursuant to this code of ethics, the member shall not participate in any ex-parte communications with other members regarding the matter at hand. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-59. - Deliberation and vote prohibited. 
No city official shall participate in the discussion, debate, deliberation or vote, or otherwise take part in the decision-making process on any agenda item, any official act or action in which he or she or member of his or her immediate family has a conflict of interest. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-60. - Duty to leave meeting. 
To avoid the appearance of impropriety, after any city official is determined to have a conflict of interest or a potential conflict of interest in any matter, the member of mayor and council shall leave his or her regular seat as a member of the council and not return to it until deliberation and action on the matter is completed. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-61. - Ethics committee. 
The mayor and council shall appoint an ethics committee consisting of three (3) persons. At least one (1) member shall be an attorney in good standing with the State Bar of Georgia. All members shall be residents of the City of Cairo, shall have not been convicted of a felony involving moral turpitude, unless the civil rights of that person have been restored for a period of ten (10) years and shall serve a three-year term. Members of the ethics committee must be approved by at least a two-thirds-vote of the mayor and council and shall be appointed initially in such manner as to permit one (1) term to terminate each year. The members of the ethics committee shall serve without compensation. A member of the ethics committee may be removed by a majority vote of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-62. - Receipt of complaints. 
(a)  All complaints against a city official shall be filed in writing under oath with the city manager and referred to the ethics committee within five (5) days in such form as may be prescribed by the ethics committee. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the ethics committee shall: 
(1)  Review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary action or is to be considered for further investigation. 
(2)  Be empowered to dismiss those complaints which are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the city official; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the ethics committee shall not deprive the complaining party of any action he or she might otherwise have at law or in equity against the respondent government servant. 
(3)  Be empowered to collect evidence and information concerning any complaint and to add to the findings and results of its investigations to the file containing such complaint. 
(4)  Be empowered to conduct probable cause investigations, to take evidence and hold hearings. Unless the complaint is found to be frivolous and unjustified, the board of ethics shall conduct a hearing according to procedures and regulations it establishes. The hearing shall be held no sooner than ten (10) days following written notice of same to the subject of the complaint, but no later than forty-five (45) days after receipt of the complaint. At the hearing the city official who is the subject of the complaint shall have the right to counsel, the right to hear and examine witnesses and evidence, present evidence and oppose or mitigate the allegations. Failure to comply with deadlines shall not invalid any otherwise valid complaint or affect the power of the ethics committee to act. 
(5)  Make recommendations to the mayor and council to invoke disciplinary action as described within this article. The mayor and council shall take action upon the recommendation of the ethics committee at the next regular meeting of mayor and council following receipt of the recommendation. 
(6)  All actions taken by the ethics committee shall be taken within thirty (30) days of receipt of the complaint. The decision by the ethics committee shall be reduced to writing and served upon all parties at interest within five (5) days of reaching a decision. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-63. - Right to appeal. 
Decisions of the mayor and council pursuant to this code of ethics for members of mayor and council shall be reviewable by the Superior Court of Grady County upon notice in writing filed within thirty (30) days of receipt of notice of the decision of the ethics committee. Review by the superior court shall be limited to an inquiry of whether there was any evidence before the mayor and council which supported the decision of the mayor and council. Provided, however, no action of the mayor and council refusing or failing to take action pursuant to this code of ethics shall be reviewable by the superior court. 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Sec. 16-64. - Penalties. 
Any violation of this code of ethics shall subject the offender to: 
(a)  Disciplinary action which may include private reprimand, public reprimand, or impeachment. 
(b)  A fine up to six hundred dollars ($600.00). 
(Ord. No. 724, § 1, 11-8-10) 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 407, adopted Aug. 26, 1991, provided for the adoption of the Cairo-Whigham-Grady County Comprehensive Land Use Plan. Such plan is not set out at length herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 17-1. - City planning commission—Membership. 
(a)  Number: The city planning commission shall consist of five (5) members, appointed by the governing body. 
(b)  Qualifications: Members of the city planning commission shall be residents of the city, and a majority shall be persons who hold no other public office in the city or county. 
(c)  Term of office: The terms of office of the members of the city planning commission shall be for five (5) years. 
(d)  Vacancies: Any vacancy in the city planning commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing body. 
(e)  Removal: The governing body may remove any member of the city planning commission for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. 
(f)  Compensation; expenses: All members of the city planning commission shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-51—2-56) 
Sec. 17-2. - Same—Organization. 
(a)  The city planning commission shall elect one of its appointive members as chairman, who shall serve for one (1) year or until such person is re-elected or a successor is elected. 
(b)  A second appointive member shall be elected as vice-chairman and shall serve for one (1) year or until re-elected or a successor is elected. 
(c)  The city planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the municipality or of the city planning commission. 
(d)  The city planning commission shall promulgate its own rules of procedure. 
(e)  The city planning commission shall determine the times of its meetings. 
(f)  All meetings of the city planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the commission shall be public records. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-57—2-59) 
Sec. 17-3. - Same—Technical assistance. 
The city planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. 
(Code 1965, § 2-60) 
Sec. 17-4. - Same—Expenditures. 
The expenditures of the city planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the governing body. 
(Code 1965, § 2-62) 
Sec. 17-5. - City-county planning commission—Appointment of representative; term of office. 
The five (5) representatives for this city on the Cairo-Whigham-Grady County Planning Commission shall be appointed by the governing body of this city, to hold office for terms of three (3) years. 
(Code 1965, § 2-77) 
Sec. 17-6. - Same—Vacancies. 
If a vacancy shall occur in any of the positions on the Cairo-Whigham-Grady County Planning Commission held by representatives of this city, such vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the governing body of this city for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1965, § 2-78) 
Sec. 17-7. - Same—Removal. 
The five (5) representatives for this city on the Cairo-Whigham-Grady County Planning Commission may be removed at any time for cause, after notice and public hearing. 
(Code 1965, § 2-79) 
Sec. 17-8. - Same—Service without compensation. 
The five (5) representatives for this city on the Cairo-Whigham-Grady County Planning Commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 2-80) 
Sec. 17-9. - Same—Reimbursement for expenses. 
The five (5) representatives for this city on the Cairo-Whigham-Grady County Planning Commission shall be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1965, § 2-81) 
Sec. 17-10. - Southwest Georgia Planning and Development Commission—Appointment of representative; term of office. 
The representative of this city on the Southwest Georgia Planning and Development Commission shall be appointed by the governing body of this city to hold office for a term of five (5) years, except that the first appointment under this section shall be for three (3) years. 
(Code 1965, § 2-68) 
Sec. 17-11. - Same—Service without compensation. 
The representative of this city shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 2-69) 
Sec. 17-12. - Same—Removal. 
The representative of this city may be removed for cause, upon written charges, after a public hearing. 
(Code 1965, § 2-70) 
Sec. 17-13. - Same—Vacancies. 
Vacancies in the office of the representative of this city shall be filled by the governing body of this city for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1965, § 2-71) 
Sec. 17-14. - Downtown development authority—Activated. 
There is hereby activated in the city the public body corporate and politic known as the "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Cairo" which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Downtown Development Authorities Law. 
(Res. of 10-11-82) 
State Law reference— Downtown Development Authorities Law, OCGA § 36-42-1 et seq. 
Sec. 17-15. - Same—Directors. 
(a)  The governing body of the city shall appoint the seven (7) members of the board of directors of the downtown development authority, each of whom shall be a taxpayer of the city, and not less than four (4) of whom either have, or represent a party who has, an economic interest in the redevelopment and revitalization of the downtown development area. 
(b)  Each of the persons named above as directors shall serve in staggered terms, two (2) for two (2) years, two (2) for four (4) years and three (3) for six (6) years. After expiration of initial terms, the terms of all directors shall be six (6) years. If at the end of the term of office of any director a successive to such director has not been elected the director whose term of office has expired shall continue to hold office until a successor is elected. 
(Res. of 10-11-82; Ord. No. 687, § 1, 4-28-08) 
Sec. 17-16. - Same—Organization. 
The board of directors hereinbefore elected shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the downtown development authorities law as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. 
(Res. of 10-11-82) 
Sec. 17-17. - Same—Development area. 
The geographical area subject to downtown development authority jurisdiction shall be defined as follows: An area bounded on the north by 3 rd Avenue, east by 3 rd Street, south by 3 rd Avenue, and west by 2 nd Street, together with properties fronting on said streets. 
(Res. of 10-11-82; Ord. No. 687, § 2, 4-28-08) 
Chapter 18 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 18-1. - Installation of pipes, etc. 
(a)  The city manager and any other officer or agent acting for the city shall not engage in the installation, construction, repair, renewal, removal or relocation of pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, towers or other equipment, appliances or other utility in, on, along, over or under any street right-of-way, other than numbered state routes, the construction or improvement of which had been undertaken, agreed to be undertaken, or had been completed by the state highway department pursuant to its authority, without due compliance with the regulations of the state highway department known as PPM 30. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, including those franchised by the city, without first securing a permit from the city manager, to install, construct, maintain, repair, renew, remove or relocate any utility facility in, on, along, over or under any city street right-of-way other than numbered state routes where the construction of or improvement on any such street right-of-way had been undertaken, or agreed to be undertaken, or which had been completed by the state highway department pursuant to its authority. 
(c)  The term "utility" as used in this section shall mean and include all publicly, privately, or cooperatively owned lines, facilities and systems for producing, transmitting or distributing communications, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil products, water, steam, waste, storm water not connected with highway drainage, and other similar services or commodities, including publicly owned fire and police signals and street lighting systems which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 149, §§ 1—3, 9-8-69) 
Sec. 18-2. - Excavations, encroachments, obstructions of physical activities. 
(a)  No person shall excavate upon or construct any building, wall or extension of or place any obstruction of any kind on any public way of the city. 
(b)  No person shall participate in any game or athletic activity or locate any equipment relating to any game or activity on any street or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 28-2; Ord. No. 792, § 1, 6-12-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 792, § 1, adopted June 12, 2017, changed the title of § 18-2 from "Excavations; encroachments; obstructions" to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference— Excavation code, § 6-180; plumber work permit, § 13-20. 
Sec. 18-3. - Operation of certain vehicles. 
No person shall operate a motorized or electric cart or vehicle including but not limited to golf carts, go-carts or all-terrain vehicles except upon the following conditions: 
(1)  No such vehicle shall be operated upon the sidewalks of the city. 
(2)  All such vehicles shall be operated on streets and roads only during daylight hours unless such vehicles shall comply with equipment regulations promulgated by the commissioner of public safety. 
(3)  All vehicles shall be operated by persons having a valid motor vehicle operators license. 
(4)  All such vehicles shall be operated in compliance with all traffic laws of the state and ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 1, 3-12-01) 
Chapter 19 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]
